Text: for the A r m y inform me whether i n

Text: the damage caused to property at Bondi

Text: fragments of star shells, crashed through

Text: the roofs of houses and flats during the

Text: firing of artillery salvoes at North Head

Speaker: NA
Text: to mark the opening of the A r m y Recruitany

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Campaign? I f so, with what result?

Text: Are steps being taken to ensure that

Text: adequate compensation will be paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: householders whose property has been

Speaker: NA
Text: damaged? Can the Minister furnish any

Text: estimate of the total damage done? Was

Text: the happening due to neglect or carelessI

Speaker: NA
Text: ness on the part of the Army authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: or was i t attributable to the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: ammunition? I n view of the damage

Speaker: NA
Text: done'to property, and the grave danger

Text: to human life, exemplified by this i

Speaker: NA
Text: cident, can the Minister i n f o r m the House

Text: of any steps that have been, or are to be,

Text: taken to prevent a recurrence ?

Text: can only say that inquiries are being

Text: the exhibition was a little too realistic

Speaker: NA

Text: IMMIGEATION.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOUTH AUSTRALIA N QUOTA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr ELTSSELL.^Has the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Immigration been drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: a report which appeared i n the Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: Advertiser on the 15th November, which

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that the Premier of South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not receiving its f a i r quota

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigrants? Has the Premier of that

Speaker: NA
Text: State made any protests to the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: or has the attention of the Minister been

Speaker: NA
Text: previously directed to the matter i n any

Speaker: NA
Text: other way?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement i n the Adelaide press attributed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Premier of South Australia, i n

Speaker: NA
Text: - which he is alleged to have stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: r South Australia is not receiving its f a i r

Speaker: NA
Text: quota of immigrants i n accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision reached at a conference of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and State Ministers held

Speaker: NA
Text: last January. I n regard to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's inquiry as to whether I received

Speaker: NA
Text: advice f r o m the Premier of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia along the lines of his reported

Speaker: NA
Text: comment i n the press, I have to inform

Speaker: NA
Text: him that I have not received any letter on

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of immigration f r o m the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier of that State since the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion of. the conference last January.

Speaker: NA
Text: am amazed at the long series of mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: statements attributed to that honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: faulty gentleman i n the newspaper report.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is reported to have stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately f or South Australia i t

Speaker: NA
Text: n - looked as though the amended quota of

Speaker: NA
Text: C,000 immigrants would not sail this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. However, he must know quite well

Speaker: NA
Text: from the reports of his officers that the

Speaker: NA
Text: target of 6,000 immigrants agreed upon

Speaker: NA
Text: at the conference in January as being

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable will be attained. He is also

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged to have said that he had not

Speaker: NA
Text: received any advice of further sailings

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigrants for South Australia since

Speaker: NA
Text: last March. The fact of the matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: that he has been advised of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people arriving on Asturias in the course

Speaker: NA
Text: of the next week or so. The number of

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants arriving on that vessel exceeds

Speaker: NA
Text: the total number of migrants landed in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia between March and the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time. The Premier has made

Speaker: NA
Text: altogether a long series of misstatements.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish he would write to me for the

Speaker: NA
Text: information when I would give him

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts. Unfortunately he cannot keep

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of immigration out of party

Speaker: NA
Text: political warfare. I n all my dealings

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Premiers and with honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on both sides of the House I

Speaker: NA
Text: have endeavoured to keep immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the arena of party politics. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have treated the Premiers fairly and I

Speaker: NA
Text: expect to be treated the same way. I ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pect them to make their addresses to me

Speaker: NA
Text: and not air their grievances, i f any, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the press before consulting me. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that there are some people com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing here under the free, and some under

Speaker: NA
Text: the assisted, system of immigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those people, however, who are paying

Speaker: NA
Text: their own way have a perfect right to say

Speaker: NA
Text: where they will live. South Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: is apparently not sufficiently progressive

Speaker: NA
Text: to attract them. I cannot be held respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible i f those people choose some other

Speaker: NA
Text: State as their place of residence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I n condemning the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: criticizing the other State Premiers who

Speaker: NA
Text: are obviously .much more progressive in

Speaker: NA
Text: their outlook than he is.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHY
Text: I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Information and Immigration whether

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is true that Asturias is on

Speaker: NA
Text: way to Australia with a. large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of British migrants, who are coming

Speaker: NA
Text: here under the free arid assisted passage

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Is the ship carrying migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: to South Australia, and i f so, what

Speaker: NA
Text: number?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I t is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: Asturias is now on its way to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: with about 1,768 new settlers. With the

Speaker: NA
Text: exception of 168 former members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Polish Army, who saw service at Tobruk,

Speaker: NA
Text: and are on their way to Tasmania, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 Maltese for whom the British Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment desired transport, all the pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sengers are migrants under the free and

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted passage scheme. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest number of migrants ever brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia in any one ship under any

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Three hundred of them are for

Speaker: NA
Text: South'Australia, bringing the total num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of migrants for that State up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 584. Other ships are sailing from Eng-

Speaker: NA
Text: land between now and the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year, also bringing migrants to South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I have not tlie slightest doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that the quota which was agreed upon

Speaker: NA
Text: with tbe Government of South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reached, i f not before Christmas,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly early in the New Year. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we can get ships we arrange for the

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation to be fully occupied.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this connexion, a recent statement by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Premier of South Australia that two

Speaker: NA
Text: ships had left Britain with practically

Speaker: NA
Text: 110 migrants on board is news to me. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have the matter investigated,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I should like to obtain some

Speaker: NA
Text: further information on it. I t seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that the Premier of South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has discovered a mare's nest.

Text: experienced i n New South "Wales i n this

Text: Wales Government. I have already ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: some system of permits primary pro-

Speaker: NA

Text: who, perhaps, would not have the same

Text: opportunity as city dwellers to get motor

Text: vehicles might not receive a f a i r deal. I t

Text: is the view of the Government that, what-

Text: ever difficulties exist, they should be over-

Text: come in the best way possible, and the

Text: permit system seems to 'be the fairest

Speaker: NA

Text: liis having been associated with State

Text: I have been correctly informed, the

Text: t^arringali. There has been no discus-

Text: TAXATION.

Text: GOVERNMENT POLICY-PROVISIONA L

Speaker: NA
Text: ASSESSMENTS.

Speaker: Mr RANKIN
Text: Ha s the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer been drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: to a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: during

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian election campaign that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the post-war era, the cost of many post-

Speaker: NA
Text: in war projects will have to ibe met from

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds of taxation, and that high

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to continue to wipe out

Speaker: NA
Text: debts incurred in the recent war? I f so,

Speaker: NA
Text: is it to be understood from, that statemenl

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government intends to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing the public at the present crippling

Speaker: NA
Text: rates?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I have not seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement purported to have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister.

Speaker: Mr RANKIN
Text: H e made it all right.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Ther e is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong with it, anyhow.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I shall ascertain the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth of the alleged statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the honorable member, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that rates of taxes have been very greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced since the termination of the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I believe that reductions have

Speaker: NA
Text: even outdistanced the hopes of the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers. I shall consider the matter.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I direct a question

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer concerning provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax payments which, in normal

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances, I should have dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: on Grievance Day. I base it on the

Speaker: NA
Text: following paragraph from a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: written to me by a man at Irymple near

Speaker: NA
Text: Mildura in the dried fruits area-

Speaker: NA
Text: As you are aware, the growers in this

Speaker: NA
Text: trict experienced a very bad season this

Speaker: NA
Text: and incomes were considerably reduced. For

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, in my own case, which is typical

Speaker: NA
Text: of others, my income was reduced to £220

Speaker: NA
Text: from an average of £500. This means that tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of provisional tax demanded (£83) is

Speaker: NA
Text: about four times as much as I would he re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to pay based on income as shown in

Speaker: NA
Text: my income tax return.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the event of income tax having been

Speaker: NA
Text: paid, when can a refund of over-payment

Speaker: NA
Text: be expected? I n view of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: growers have had to arrange for over-

Speaker: NA
Text: drafts from their banks or advances from

Speaker: NA
Text: packing sheds in order to pay their in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come tax, will the Commissioner of Taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion repay interest on overpayments by

Speaker: NA
Text: them? Further, is it intended that this

Speaker: NA
Text: form of taxation shall be continued?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Th e sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax legislation relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: application of the provisional tax system,

Speaker: NA
Text: were given considerable thought by the

Speaker: NA
Text: .special committee of members which was

Speaker: NA
Text: set up to consider taxation questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem involved is not easy

Speaker: NA
Text: to solve. Salary and wage earners

Speaker: NA
Text: have weekly deductions made from

Speaker: NA
Text: their pay to meet their tax liabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties; but the only way to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: the " pay as you earn " system to income

Speaker: NA
Text: I'nrnerp who are not in receipt of wages

Speaker: NA
Text: or salaries, is to make provisional tax

Speaker: NA
Text: assessments based on income earned in

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous year. There are cases-

Speaker: NA
Text: that mentioned by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Wimmera is one-wher e a taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: may receive a high income in one year,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a relatively low figure in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: year. His provisional tax for the second

Speaker: NA
Text: of these years is based on his high income

Speaker: NA
Text: in the previousyear, and he may be

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to meet this commitment. These

Speaker: NA
Text: I cases are dealt with quite easily. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation authorities receive a satisfac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory assurance- I imagine that such an

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance could readily be given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case mentioned by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber-th e taxpayer can have the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of his provisional tax held in abeyance

Speaker: NA
Text: until his income for that year has been

Speaker: NA
Text: ascertained. I f , however, he pays the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax and subsequently finds that his

Speaker: NA
Text: income has been much less than that for

Speaker: NA
Text: which the provisional tax was assessed,

Speaker: NA
Text: he will receive his refund when his assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is sent to him. I am sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member will find that in any

Speaker: NA
Text: dis- case of the kind mentioned by him to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: year, the Commissioner for Taxation or one

Speaker: NA
Text: of his deputies will be prepared imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately to grant relief by allowing pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of either part or all of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visional tax owing, to be held in

Speaker: NA
Text: abeyance until the actual income has been

Speaker: NA
Text: ascertained. The taxation authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: of course would require definite evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of inability to pay. Mere hearsay evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence would not be sufficient.

Text: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT.

Text: AUSTRALIA' S FUTURE .

Text: Accordin g to a report

Speaker: NA
Text: that appeared in the week-end press,

Text: the American Ambassador to Australia.

Text: Mr Butler, who is now in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, gave an encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: review of Australia's future at a press

Speaker: NA
Text: conference. He praised the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: steel industry and the proposed Ameri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can-Australian iron and steel venture,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: panies were operating successfully in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and many others were likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: follow because Australia was heading for

Speaker: NA
Text: an economic boom, I n view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pessimism of some individuals in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, I ask the Prime Minister

Text: whether he shares the American Ambas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sador's thoughtful optimism. Also, can

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman say to

Speaker: NA
Text: what extent American capital is flowing

Speaker: NA
Text: into this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: MT. CHIFLEY -I t is quite evident to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody who has an open mind on the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject that never before in the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia has there been such great

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and industrial activity as there

Speaker: NA
Text: is to-day. People competent to express

Speaker: NA
Text: an opinion say that never before has so

Speaker: NA
Text: much interest been shown in the expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion or setting up of new industries. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the pessimism of which the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member speaks is largely political

Speaker: NA
Text: and is not real. I have said before, ']

Speaker: NA
Text: think, in this chamber that a grand

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity exists for the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industries, secondary, cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly, and, I believe, primary. I realize

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe factors that operate to-day always

Speaker: NA
Text: create the danger of an inflationary trend

Speaker: NA
Text: in the economic life of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned that in the House several

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago, and I do not want to be guilty

Speaker: NA
Text: of its repetition. Considering everything,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, I do not think this country has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever experienced such satisfactory con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions for the expansion of industry as

Speaker: NA
Text: exist, to-day.

Text: The protocol was signed on behalf of

Text: Minister for External Affairs (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt), and tbe following statement was

Speaker: NA
Text: issued by him on behalf of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government under-

Speaker: NA
Text: takes to apply provisionally, provided

Speaker: NA
Text: all other countries do likewise, the

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff reductions negotiated witb the

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries whose representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: have been engaged in Geneva during

Speaker: NA
Text: the greater part of 1947. This action

Speaker: NA
Text: will be consequent upon my signing,

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the protocol of provisional appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of general agreement on tariffs

Speaker: NA
Text: and trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government will

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: from the 18th November. At a later

Speaker: NA
Text: date, the Government will decide

Speaker: NA
Text: whether to recommend to the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that the provisional agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: be confirmed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The breadth of the negotiations con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted by a committee established by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Economic and Social Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations is without prece-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent. More than 120 separate negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions ranging over a vast number of

Speaker: NA
Text: products were completed by representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives who met to attempt mutually

Speaker: NA
Text: advantageous arrangements to free the

Speaker: NA
Text: channels of world trade. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated with a full conviction of

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits to be gained, not only to

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, but by the. whole world from

Speaker: NA
Text: a satisfactory settlement and a selective

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of present trade barriers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The negotiations have to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered in the light of concurrent

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to get agreements, in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of a charter from an International

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Organization, to commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: upon countries to maintain employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the demand for goods, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are the basis of trade, and to adhere

Speaker: NA
Text: to agreed rules of good trade conduct.

Speaker: NA
Text: These commitments are intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement those which the members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Nations have already

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted in the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: charter-namely , to promote jointly

Speaker: NA
Text: and severally, higher standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: living, full employment, and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions of economic and social progress

Speaker: NA
Text: and development.

Speaker: NA
Text: The project embarked upon by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic and Social Council, through

Speaker: NA
Text: its preparatory committee and the

Speaker: NA
Text: world conference which is to assemble

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly in Havana, is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive endeavours of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. The progress already made

Speaker: NA
Text: in tariff negotiations and the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: by a substantial number of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to bring tariff reductions into

Speaker: NA
Text: provisional effect lay a sound basis for

Speaker: NA
Text: successful achievement of a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in world trading condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and for a solution of the present

Speaker: NA
Text: economic crisis.

Text: filling of Commonwealth loans. Much

Speaker: NA
Text: jmblicity has been made of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth loans have been fully

Speaker: NA
Text: subscribed when, as a matter of fact, a

Speaker: NA
Text: large amount of the deposits of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the savings bank has been utilized by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank for that pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose. I t is apparent that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank has been quietly transfer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ring to the Treasurer money belonging to

Speaker: NA
Text: depositors in the Commonwealth Sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings Bank in order to enable the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman to boast that his

Speaker: NA
Text: loans have been successfully floated. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other principal source from which the

Speaker: NA
Text: money might be obtained is tho

Speaker: NA
Text: £268,000,000 which the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank holds as trustee for the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. I n order to make the position

Speaker: NA
Text: clear to any one who may not readily

Speaker: NA
Text: understand it, may I explain that the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks were compelled, first by

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Regulations, and later

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Banking Act of 1945, to deposit

Speaker: NA
Text: certain surplus funds Avith the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank. They have been paid

Speaker: NA
Text: interest on those funds at the rate of \

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. On the opposite side of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank's profit and loss account

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an amount of £274,000,000,.

Speaker: NA
Text: which is held in government securities,

Speaker: NA
Text: including treasury-bills. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: practically the whole of the trading banks'

Speaker: NA
Text: special accounts have again come to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The trading banks are paid

Speaker: NA
Text: interest at the rate of per cent., but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank is paid 1 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: on treasury-bills, so that i t is making a

Speaker: NA
Text: profit of 100 per cent, on money that

Speaker: NA
Text: properly belongs to the trading banks.

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Tha t is a normal opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Whateve r expert

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge the honorable' member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth may have, a duty devolves upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister to inform the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and the country. The third method by

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Commonwealth Bank may

Speaker: NA
Text: finance the acquisition of the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks is that of inflating the currency.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has been suggested by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Perth.

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: I did not suggest any

Speaker: NA
Text: such thing.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member said that the banks' shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: might be paid either in bonds or in cash.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where are the bonds to be found ? Where

Speaker: NA
Text: is the cash to be found ? We are entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to be given some information in answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to those questions. I f the funds are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained by means of inflating the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rency, that means that there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: further depreciation of the value of money

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore a further depreciation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the accounts of savings banks

Speaker: NA
Text: depositors. Should this £100,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation take place, such depositors

Speaker: NA
Text: will find that a deposit of, say, £100 will

Speaker: NA
Text: be capable, of buying only £75 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods. These are merely speculative pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities, and I do not know the answer.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Ver y speculative, too.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Tha t is the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: that I wanted. The Prime Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only one who can resolve this specula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and the people are entitled to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the information which he can give to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. He must be able to answer my

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. I n a democratic community,

Speaker: NA
Text: there can be no legitimate reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: secrecy in this matter. This cannot be a

Speaker: NA
Text: secret transaction because, before the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal to nationalize the banks was for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mulated, the Prime Minister must have

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed with the Governor of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank the means of financing

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme. He ought to tell the country

Speaker: NA
Text: what he proposes to do. The people are

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to know whether there is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: an inflation of the currency by

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 in order to compensate the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders of the private banks, or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Commonwealth Bank pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to use money that has been deposited

Speaker: NA
Text: with the trading banks. Those are the

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives. The Prime Minister ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to answer me. The country is entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: an answer.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Hindmarsh) [4.44].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Th e clauses now before the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for the payment of compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the way in which i t will be paid.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: The y do not.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Th e bill is clear

Speaker: NA
Text: on the matter. What the shareholders in

Speaker: NA
Text: the private banks want to know is how

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be paid for their shares. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill provides definitely that the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be bought, at the very least, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: market prices ruling on the 15th August,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1947. Those are the lowest prices which

Speaker: NA
Text: can be paid for them, and i t is possible

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Federal Court of Claims may

Speaker: NA
Text: award a higher rate of compensation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party ( Mr Fadden) has referred to taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the rates and charges levied by

Speaker: NA
Text: local government bodies, but they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with at all in these clauses. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: for financing the acquisition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks should be explained. My

Speaker: NA
Text: contention is that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank is able to finance the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation. I was rather amused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the question posed by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Richmond ( Mr Anthony), who

Speaker: NA
Text: asked whether payment would be made in

Speaker: NA
Text: bonds or in bank notes. Would any per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son who owns shares in a private bank

Speaker: NA
Text: from which he receives a good dividend

Speaker: NA
Text: be likely to take a large sum of bank

Speaker: NA
Text: notes and put i t in safe deposit where it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not earn interest for him? I can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not imagine that shareholders would take

Speaker: NA
Text: bank notes in payment for their shares

Speaker: NA
Text: and not put them to any use. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable gentleman's remarks about

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation appear to me to have very little

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to this discussion. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member also asked whether the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank would have sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: security i f shares were bought with bonds.

Speaker: NA
Text: I point out that people who hold shares

Speaker: NA
Text: in private banks consider those shares to

Speaker: NA
Text: be very good asset3. I f the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank takes over those shares, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not lose any of their value as

Speaker: NA
Text: security.

Speaker: NA
Text: The group of clauses which the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee is now considering deals with

Speaker: NA
Text: assets. I f the Commonwealth Bank pays

Speaker: NA
Text: for certain hank buildings and other

Speaker: NA
Text: assets when it takes over from the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, it will be able to use those assets as

Speaker: NA
Text: security. I t seems to me that honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite are very hard-pushed

Speaker: NA
Text: to find some concrete objection to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals within this group of clauses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those proposals constitute the crux of

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure. Honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site may talk as much as they like about

Speaker: NA
Text: but the fact remains that, when the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank takes over the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: and buildings of the private banks those

Speaker: NA
Text: assets will remain just as valuable as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are to-day. The only difference will be

Speaker: NA
Text: that certain people will not continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: derive benefit from those assets as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing now, and that any lowering of

Speaker: NA
Text: the profit derived from the use of those

Speaker: NA
Text: assets will be to the advantage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people generally. The Leader of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Country party ( Mr Fadden)

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that profits from the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of those assets will not go to general

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue but will be used to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: our national debt. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: most people will agree that, i f the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth has a business undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: whose profits reduce Australia's national

Speaker: NA
Text: debt, that undertaking will be of great

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage to the people, because it will

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the Government to reduce taxes.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the national debt is lowered, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will be able to reduce rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax which are now necessary to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the demands of the national debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: These clauses need not be debated at

Speaker: NA
Text: great length, because they are virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: self-explanatory. I admit that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some technical details on which honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members may wish to have information,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the general principles embodied in

Speaker: NA
Text: the clauses are set out very clearly. They

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that the shares of the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks will be taken over at the market

Speaker: NA
Text: values prevailing on 15th August last, or

Speaker: NA
Text: at any higher value which the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of Claims may consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders are entitled to receive.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: Ho w will the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank pay for them?

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: I f the right hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable gentleman sold a block of land, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would be paid for it in one of two ways,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, by cheque or by bank notes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are the usual methods of payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f he were paid with bank notes, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would be anxious to lodge them

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately with his'bank. He would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be anxious to carry them with him.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, whether the shareholders are paid in

Speaker: NA
Text: notes or by cheque, the money will go

Speaker: NA
Text: back into banking accounts, and as there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be no private banks in existence after

Speaker: NA
Text: the passage of this legislation the money

Speaker: NA
Text: will be returned to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank, with the exception of that portion

Speaker: NA
Text: of it which will go to the State banks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bank will be called upon to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a lot of promissory notes. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is general banking practice, and it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be encumbent upon the bank to observe

Speaker: NA
Text: that practice, provided, of course, that

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate security exists. Obviously the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank would not accept a promissory note

Speaker: NA
Text: that lacked adequate security. The

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders can rest assured that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be treated fairly. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: no honorable member opposite will argue

Speaker: NA
Text: that the court will not properly assess

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the shares and assets of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks. Even those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: vigorously opposed to the nationalization

Speaker: NA
Text: of the private banks can have no objection

Speaker: NA
Text: to the manner in which it. is proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to compensate those who will be affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by this proposal. No valid argument

Speaker: NA
Text: has been advanced against the compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion provisions, and in the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: such argument their retention cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: questioned. The clauses now under dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion have no relation to income tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: or to payments to local government

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies. Reference has been made to

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters merely to cloud the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has stated that ex

Speaker: NA
Text: gratia payments will be made to muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipal bodies and I am satisfied that these

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will be reasonable.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wimmera) [4.54].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Th e honorable member for Hindmarsh

Speaker: NA
Text: has made a long speech, but so far as I

Speaker: NA
Text: can gather all he has said is that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation will be paid by cheque or in

Speaker: NA
Text: notes. He has not touched the deeper

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of the effect of these payments upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy of this country. The point

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honorable member missed is that

Speaker: NA
Text: neither money nor any other means of

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange can be produced by laws.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wealth can be produced only by labour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The passage of a bill does not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessarily produce a sound economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley) has

Speaker: NA
Text: been asked to explain fully, or at least

Speaker: NA
Text: in some detail, how the finance is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: arranged to pay the shareholders of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks. That is a simple question.

Speaker: NA
Text: When an individnal undertakes a private

Speaker: NA
Text: transaction, the source of his money is

Speaker: NA
Text: his own private concern; but when a

Speaker: NA
Text: government undertakes to purchase goods

Speaker: NA
Text: or chattels, the people are the real pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: chasers, and the Prime Minister is called

Speaker: NA
Text: upon automatically to say what assets

Speaker: NA
Text: belonging to the people are to be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to finance the transaction.

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: Flinders) [4.56] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: reply given by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hindmarsh ( Mr Thompson) to

Speaker: NA
Text: points raised by the Opposition is almost

Speaker: NA
Text: us vague as the clauses we are now con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering. There are two aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation question: the first concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders themselves and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Hindmarsh has

Speaker: NA
Text: said'- I do not know with what

Speaker: NA
Text: authority-tha t they will be paid either

Speaker: NA
Text: in notes or by cheque.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: O r bonds.

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: Tha t is the very point

Speaker: NA
Text: that I wish to make. What type of

Speaker: NA
Text: bond will they be? When the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom Government bought the British

Speaker: NA
Text: coal mines, the shareholders were paid

Speaker: NA
Text: in non-negotiable bonds. Are we to

Speaker: NA
Text: assume that the shareholders in the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian trading banks are to be paid in

Speaker: NA
Text: bonds that cannot be sold until they

Speaker: NA
Text: have matured perhaps 10 years or 25

Speaker: NA
Text: years hence? That is a. point that must

Speaker: NA
Text: be cleared up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second point is the manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the operation of taking over the private

Speaker: NA
Text: trading banks at a cost of approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 is to be financed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Recently the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: bought bank shares for approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000. We do not know yet how this

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase is being financed and I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that the public, quite apart from mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of this committee, is entitled to some

Speaker: NA
Text: information on the matter. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Chifley) knows very well

Speaker: NA
Text: that inflation could be caused by adding

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 to the currency. I that

Speaker: NA
Text: to be done? That is a question to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee should have a definite,

Speaker: NA
Text: answer from the right honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man and I trust that he will give a

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory reply. So far, no attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made to answer this question,

Speaker: NA
Text: although it has been asked on several

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sub-clause 1 (b) of clause 39 provides

Speaker: NA
Text: that persons entitled to compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: shall put in their claims not less than

Speaker: NA
Text: two months after the shares have become

Speaker: NA
Text: vested in the Commonwealth. This period

Speaker: NA
Text: is far too short, particularly for people

Speaker: NA
Text: living abroad, whose shares may not be

Speaker: NA
Text: available, and who may not even know

Speaker: NA
Text: what is taking place. A much longer

Speaker: NA
Text: period should be specified. That also

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to clause 41, which says-

Speaker: NA
Text: A person who has in his possession tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: share certificate in respect of any shares which

Speaker: NA
Text: have become vested in the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: under section thirteen of this act, shall, not

Speaker: NA
Text: later than two months after those shares

Speaker: NA
Text: became so vested, deliver up that certificate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Coiiinionweatlh Bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: Penalty: One thousand pounds.

Speaker: NA
Text: That seems an extraordinarily severe

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty for something that may be noth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing more than inability to obtain a share

Speaker: NA
Text: certificate or lack of knowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: what has occurred. That penalty might

Speaker: NA
Text: well be reviewed. Whereas shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: are given only two months in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with this provision and other

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the measure, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank is granted no less than six

Speaker: NA
Text: months in .which to act in respect of any

Speaker: NA
Text: action to be taken by it. Surely, i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonweatlh Bank is to have six

Speaker: NA
Text: months in which to act, shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: should be allowed six months too. Ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planation is also required of clause 40,

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Where a notice is not given under the

Speaker: NA
Text: last preceding section in relation to any shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of compensation payable in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the acquisition of those shares shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: payable to the person whose name is for the

Speaker: NA
Text: time being entered in the compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: register as the owner of the right to be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation in respect of the acquisition of

Speaker: NA
Text: those shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The amount of compensation payable

Speaker: NA
Text: shall, unless agreed upon, be determined by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Court. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: That means that the court may determine

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of compensation to be pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, but sub-clause 3 provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: The making of an agreement under the last

Speaker: NA
Text: s

Speaker: NA
Text: preceding sub-section shall be subject to tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does (hat mean? Does it mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer will have power to sweep

Speaker: NA
Text: 'aside any agreement reached between

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders, or their agents, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank? I f it does not,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the point of that condition? I t

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to destroy the effect of negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: for an agreemerit i f the agreement is

Speaker: NA
Text: finally to be subject to the approval of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer. The same provision is

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in sub-clause 2 of clause 43,

Speaker: NA
Text: which deals with the settlement of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensation by agreement-*-

Speaker: NA
Text: The making of an agreement under the last

Speaker: NA
Text: preceding sub-section shall be subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why i3 that necessary ? Surely, i f an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is made between the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank and the person concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: that, agreement should be considered final.

Speaker: NA
Text: I! see no reason for the provision. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should the Treasurer be allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: intervene? Why, indeed, should he inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: vene at all?

Speaker: Mr FRASER
Text: Eden-Monaro) [5.3] -

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to see the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: this discussion has developed and to note

Speaker: NA
Text: that Opposition members are now con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fining their attention to the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which payment to shareholders of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private trading banks will be financed.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have apparently completely aban-

Speaker: NA
Text: doned their earlier statements in attack-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this bill, that the rights of ike share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders will be destroyed and their assets

Speaker: NA
Text: confiscated or paid for at less than fair

Speaker: NA
Text: value. Those Statements were made

Speaker: NA
Text: when the proposal to nationalize the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks was announced.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: B y whom?

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member cannot name one

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member who made them.

Speaker: Mr FRASER
Text: Thos e statements were

Speaker: NA
Text: made on behalf of. the Opposition parties.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: B y whom?

Speaker: Mr FRASER
Text: The y were made in

Speaker: NA
Text: every newspaper, over every Commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: radio station, and on platforms in hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dreds of towns throughout Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people know that they were made because

Speaker: NA
Text: the statements aroused great concern

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst such members of the public as

Speaker: NA
Text: were prepared to trust the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The public should realize that proof of

Speaker: NA
Text: the incorrectness of the statements i.i

Speaker: NA
Text: afforded by the fact that Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members, in discussing the provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of compensation, no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: make such preposterous claims. 'Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion members have confined themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: to the manner in which payment is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be made. They appear to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively answered by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Hindmarsh ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thompson). The payments will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made with bonds, cheques, or cash, as

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders prefer. I n what other ways

Speaker: NA
Text: could payment be made ? To the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which shareholders prefer to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: government bonds in place of -dividend-

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing shares that they now possess, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to enjoy a satisfactory in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come, and no final cost to the community
