Text: wherewithal necessary to negotiate the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase of the assets of the trading

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, I used an incorrect figure. I said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the total excess of assets over lia-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities of the Commonwealth Bank was

Speaker: NA
Text: £34,000,000; However, I have since read

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report and balance-sheet of tb*

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Savings Bank as at the

Speaker: NA
Text: 30th June, 1947, that the capital reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: funds and the special reserves, which of

Speaker: NA
Text: course represent the excess of assets over

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities, amount to £22,000,000. I f I

Speaker: NA
Text: could acquire £100,000,000 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets with a backing of only £22,000,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: I should consider that I had negotiated

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinarily satisfactory deal, and

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, should regard myself as a wizard

Speaker: NA
Text: of finance. The method of purchase pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed by the Prime Minister, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me to be a crazy system of finance

Speaker: NA
Text: having no virtue whatever. When he was

Speaker: NA
Text: gibed at with regard -to the depreciated

Speaker: NA
Text: currency in Australia, the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter said, " Why talk about depreciated

Speaker: NA
Text: currency? The fact is that people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom can purchase 40 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, less, and in the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America 60 per cent, less, than people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can purchase with an equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of money. Therefore, we are in

Speaker: NA
Text: an extremely good position". Notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing how the right honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man may attempt to gloss over the depre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation of our currency, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: £1 to-day will purchase only the quantity

Speaker: NA
Text: of goods that could have been purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: for 12s. before the war. The truth is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government proposes to take over the

Speaker: NA
Text: One assets of the private banks with an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flated currency. Wc have seen the dire

Speaker: NA
Text: results of the transfer of assets i n otheii

Speaker: NA
Text: countries inwhich currency haa become

Speaker: NA
Text: excessively inflated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gentleman said that

Speaker: NA
Text: lie could not imagine the shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: accepting bank notes' in payment for their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares. He declared that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: want tohave some form of investment

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they would not regard notes as

Speaker: NA
Text: an investment. Therefore he had no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that bonds or cheques would be

Speaker: NA
Text: issued by the Commonwealth Bank, i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders so desired, to liquidate its

Speaker: NA
Text: indebtedness' to them. This statement

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves' investigation. Let us examine

Speaker: NA
Text: it. The people who originally purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: trading bank shares did so in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure investments. They did not buy

Speaker: NA
Text: shares merely to acquire an easily realiz-

Speaker: NA
Text: able asset. They wanted to obtain a

Speaker: NA
Text: return from the money so invested'. I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, such purchases were a safeguard.

Speaker: NA
Text: They provided a guaranteed uniform

Speaker: NA
Text: return over s period of years; which the

Speaker: NA
Text: buyers wanted for reasons best known to

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. As soon as those shares are

Speaker: NA
Text: taken over, the possibility of earning

Speaker: NA
Text: money by investment of the proceeds im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately disappears. The investor then

Speaker: NA
Text: will have nothing but a cheque account

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Commonwealth Bank, or bonds,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the case may be. I n either case, he will

Speaker: NA
Text: lose a certain percentage of that which

Speaker: NA
Text: he originally sought to secure by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: investment. Therefore, i t seems to me

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government has an added obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to pay compensation to the share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders for the loss of returns which they

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to receive from gilt-edged invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I f the Commonwealth. Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: liquidates, its obligations to the share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders by means of cheques, those per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons will be left to choose between two

Speaker: NA
Text: unsatisfactory alternatives. I f they wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to secure a return greater than that pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the bonds' which the Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister has mentioned, they must withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: their money from the cheque accounts and

Speaker: NA
Text: invest it, probably in some industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking. But where will they be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest it ? With the threat of socializaby

Speaker: NA
Text: tion hanging over the heads of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, they are not likely to take

Speaker: NA
Text: chances with such investments lest their

Speaker: NA
Text: money should be lost overnight. I t seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to me, therefore, that' these cheque

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts will be operated upon ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: and bank notes will be paid out to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawals. This will result in the

Speaker: NA
Text: whittling down of the shareholders' capi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal holdings. The final effect will be

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent to the acquisition o£ shares by

Speaker: NA
Text: means of the exchange of bank notes.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will mean that the shares will be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken over with an inflated currency,

Speaker: NA
Text: because most of them were purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago when the Australian £ 1 was

Speaker: NA
Text: worth approximately £1. To-day, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: have pointed out, the purchasing power

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian £1 is approximately 12s.

Speaker: NA
Text: This sort of thing has been practised by

Speaker: NA
Text: financiers through the ages. I t is equi-

Speaker: NA
Text: valent to taking advantage of inflated

Speaker: NA
Text: currency for the purpose of acquiring

Speaker: NA
Text: some asset on advantageous terms' to the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchaser. Such a transaction by a go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment cannot be condoned. I f finance

Speaker: NA
Text: is to remain on a sound footing in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, the Government must have backing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the cheques which it will pay to the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders of the private banks. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever; the excess of assets over liabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Commonwealth Bank amounts to

Speaker: NA
Text: only £22,000,000. Yet the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to acquire assets worth £100,000,000!

Speaker: NA
Text: Now I put my finger on the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: weakness in the Government's scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already we know that the special accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the trading banks lodged with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank amount to no less

Speaker: NA
Text: than £268,000,000. That will provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: backing for the cheques which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: issued for the acquisition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 worth of assets. What are

Speaker: NA
Text: we to think, of a government that, is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to use an amount of. £26S,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been extracted from, the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks by force under the legislation of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945, and deposited with the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank, as backing for cheques

Speaker: NA
Text: issued' as payment for the assets of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trading banks? I n his wordy speech on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter, all that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said was that the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: might issue bonds, or pay the shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: cheque. As I have shown, an examina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the assets and liabilities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank, reveals that ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to sound banking practice, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bank could not make available sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: funds for the purpose of this legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless it had something more behind, it.

Speaker: NA
Text: That something, of course, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: £268,000,000 in the special account, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that money belongs to the trading hanks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 40 is rather interesting. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with the payment of compensation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second and third sub-clauses state-

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The amount nf compensation payable

Speaker: NA
Text: shall, unless agreed upon, lie determined by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Court and not in any other manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The milking of uu agreement under the

Speaker: NA
Text: last preceding sub-section shall be subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: the approval of the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the Prime Minister has said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth Bank gives an

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance that it can negotiate this deal,

Speaker: NA
Text: the arrangement will be subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the Treasurer. Obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank could not negotiate even one

Speaker: NA
Text: word of an agreement off its own bat.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t must await political direction. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer must approve any arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, agreement, or contract entered into

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Commonwealth and the share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Clark) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member's time

Speaker: NA
Text: has expired.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Melbourne-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for Information and Minister for Immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration) [8.12] -Th e clauses encom-

Speaker: NA
Text: passed in this part of the bill cover some

Speaker: NA
Text: of its most important features. Clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 46 prohibits the carrying on of banking

Speaker: NA
Text: business by private hanks. Other clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with compensation for the acquisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of shares and the method by which

Speaker: NA
Text: settlements are to be reached. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe really important clause in this group

Speaker: NA
Text: is that which provides that private banks

Speaker: NA
Text: shall never again be permitted to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: on business in Australia. One would

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine from all the noise that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made about the taking over of the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: fhat something revolutionary was being

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted. I t has been said that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the first step in a ten-year plan of sociali-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation. Nothing could be more false.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation, and in particular the

Speaker: NA
Text: clause to which I have directed attention,

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes to nationalize banking. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a means to an end. I t is an end in

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, and has no reference to any pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal to socialize or nationalize other

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings. As I pointed out in my

Speaker: NA
Text: second-reading speech, we have not the

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional power even to socialize a

Speaker: NA
Text: lolly shop. But we are concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: the continuation of private banking in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, because we believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: public credit of the nation should be

Speaker: NA
Text: handled by the elected representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation and not by 50 or 60 bank

Speaker: NA
Text: directors who control the destinies of nine

Speaker: NA
Text: trading banks. I f this legislation were

Speaker: NA
Text: never passed, there would still be fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: banks for the people to deal with twelve

Speaker: NA
Text: months hence than there are now. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a 'merger on the way to completion

Speaker: NA
Text: between the National Bank of Australasia

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited and the Queensland National

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank Limited, and there was a proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: for a merger between two English banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Union Bank of Australia Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Bank of Australasia. Negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for this second merger had pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressed to a certain point when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: decided by the directors of the banks con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that nothing further should be

Speaker: NA
Text: done in the direction of,completing the

Speaker: NA
Text: amalgamation until the effect of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation had been determined in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, and possibly, ultimately,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the courts. So, when honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite talk about a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: banks being available for the people to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with, I point out that that number

Speaker: NA
Text: is continually 'diminishing. I n 1917

Speaker: NA
Text: it was 23, in 1947 it is nine, and should

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation find disfavour in the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court on the ground that it is ultra

Speaker: NA
Text: vires the Constitution, there would only

Speaker: NA
Text: be seven banks by the end of next year

Speaker: NA
Text: and, no doubt, fewer later on. Ultimately,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should reach the point when there were

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps two or three, or even one. Thus,

Speaker: NA
Text: the much-vaunted right of the people to

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer their accounts from one bank to

Speaker: NA
Text: another is proved to be a nullity. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day there is a complete understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: between the private trading banks.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: T o what clause is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister referring!

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I ! am dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the prohibition of private banking. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important clause, as the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman will perceive. Mr L. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCConnan, the chief manager of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Bank of Australasia Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a radio talk not long ago, sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: prove that, after all, the people, and not,

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders, owned the banks. These

Speaker: NA
Text: were his words-

Speaker: NA
Text: The banks are just concerns established by

Speaker: NA
Text: the people to look after their personal finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial affairs and to carry out their wishes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bald facts of the Australian banking system

Speaker: NA
Text: are perfectly plain. The hanks have been

Speaker: NA
Text: created by the people, they are owned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: people, and they are controlled by the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: And that's the democratic way.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is Mr MCGonnan speaking-

Speaker: NA
Text: Why should any government interfere with

Speaker: NA
Text: this democratic arrangement?

Speaker: NA
Text: If all the shareholders in the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks resided in this country, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCConnan might be able to say at least

Speaker: NA
Text: that these banks were owned by 70,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, that they functioned in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interest of 70,000 Australians, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the profits went to 70,000 Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders. But the truth of the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, although there are 70,000 share-"

Speaker: NA
Text: holders, only 35,000 of them live in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I have before me a very infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mative table, which shows the profits

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the trading banks between

Speaker: NA
Text: IS93 and 1946. I n those years the aggre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate profits of tlie trading banks-

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe not the net profits-amounte d

Speaker: NA
Text: profit, made out of banking, went

Speaker: NA
Text: to 70,000 shareholders. I f the divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the profit was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same ratio as the division of shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: inside Australia and outside Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: £60,000,000 of profit made out of banking

Speaker: NA
Text: went to people who have never seen Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia or even lived here at all.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: I s that gross or net

Speaker: NA
Text: profit?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I iuu speaking of

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregate profit. The net profit may be

Speaker: NA
Text: At any rate, approximately £50,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: of profit went to people whose interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country between 1893 and 1946-

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders have never numbered

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 70,000 at any time-di d not

Speaker: NA
Text: even know where Sydney, Melbourne, or

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane were. All they knew was that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was a continent out of which

Speaker: NA
Text: they were making profit. To-day we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing our best to let them know where the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital is, because any profit

Speaker: NA
Text: that is to be made out of banking in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country should go to Australian citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e people whose labour makes Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia prosperous, and whose services, like

Speaker: NA
Text: those of their parents and grandparents,

Speaker: NA
Text: have made this country what it is. i f

Speaker: NA
Text: for no other reason than that, half of

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders in the private banks

Speaker: NA
Text: have never seen Australia and are not in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terested in this land except for profit

Speaker: NA
Text: making, we should nationalize the banks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The private banks, i f they were wise in

Speaker: NA
Text: their own generation, would have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: that their shares were transferred to an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian register; but they were selfish

Speaker: NA
Text: and greedy, and wanted to make what

Speaker: NA
Text: profit they could and take it out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. But the banks which are sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to help the people in time of need,

Speaker: NA
Text: and are supposed to be most helpful in

Speaker: NA
Text: time of depression, present, this unique

Speaker: NA
Text: picture to Australians that, whereas in

Speaker: NA
Text: the depression years most industries paid

Speaker: NA
Text: no profit at all, while all industries, more

Speaker: NA
Text: or less were endangered, and some indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries had to call on reserves to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: going, no bank in Australia during that

Speaker: NA
Text: period was conducted at other than a

Speaker: NA
Text: profit. Every single bank in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: made a profit during each year

Speaker: NA
Text: of the depression. They made very

Speaker: NA
Text: big profits before the depression,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they made reasonable profits

Speaker: NA
Text: during the depression, i f we have

Speaker: NA
Text: some regard to the condition of other

Speaker: NA
Text: people. The English, Scottish and Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Bank, which refused from 1893 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946 to pay those who held interminable

Speaker: NA
Text: stock sums amounting to £2^000,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: paid dividends as high as 20 per cent, in

Speaker: NA
Text: some years, whilst the average divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dend of the banks was approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 14 per cent, per annum

Speaker: NA
Text: when the depression commenced. To-

Speaker: NA
Text: day, the banks are not making such

Speaker: NA
Text: great profits; but it was not this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which curtailed their profits. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: was our predecessors in the war years

Speaker: NA
Text: who told the banks that they were not

Speaker: NA
Text: to be allowed to invest surplus funds in

Speaker: NA
Text: war loans, or make advances to other

Speaker: NA
Text: people to invest in war loans, so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: banks could make a profit on a profit as

Speaker: NA
Text: they did during World War I . I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: a government of which the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Warringah ( Mr Spender)

Speaker: NA
Text: was a member which restrained the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: in that way in the national interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the honorable member had respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of government he was prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to do something to protect the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest, but now he is out of government

Speaker: NA
Text: he is thoroughly irresponsible. A l l he

Speaker: NA
Text: has done in this debate is to barrack for

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie banks. He does not care what profits

Speaker: NA
Text: they make. I t does not matter what the.

Speaker: NA
Text: future might hold; we say that the banks

Speaker: NA
Text: must be nationalized. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: says that they should not :be nationalized.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wha t do the people

Speaker: NA
Text: say?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e people say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's 1945 banking legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion should be supported; and that they

Speaker: NA
Text: returned this Government after the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of that legislation. But neither

Speaker: NA
Text: the party to which the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Wimmera ( Mr Turnbull) belongs,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor that to Avhich the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Warringah belongs, has stated where

Speaker: NA
Text: it stands with respect to the 1945 legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: Yes , I did.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Doe s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman speak for the Liberal party?

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: I express the same

Speaker: NA
Text: views as the Liberal party expresses.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman and his party-an d I em-

Speaker: NA
Text: phasize the party aspect-hav e not de-

Speaker: NA
Text: clared their attitude with respect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945 banking legislation. So unsatisfac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory is their negative approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: this question that the Sydney Sunday

Speaker: NA
Text: Sun last Sunday published a leader

Speaker: NA
Text: headed- I hope that the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Menzies) does not

Speaker: NA
Text: mind when I read the language-

Speaker: NA
Text: " Menzies must remove this doubt",

Speaker: NA
Text: which stated that the Liberal party must

Speaker: NA
Text: say where it stands with respect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945 banking legislation.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I read that article

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day, and it contains a grossly untrue

Speaker: NA
Text: statement.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman can have that out with the

Speaker: NA
Text: editor of the Sunday Sun.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Th e article contains a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement that I said that i f we won we

Speaker: NA
Text: would repeal the banking legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: No such statement was contained in my

Speaker: NA
Text: policy speech.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman must make himself right

Speaker: NA
Text: with his own supporters on that point;

Speaker: NA
Text: but, at any rate, even i f what he says be

Speaker: NA
Text: correct he ha9 still to declare his attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the 1945 legislation. He did not

Speaker: NA
Text: do it before the 1946 elections.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I did it in this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: in plain terms.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Di d the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman support the 1945

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation ?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: I n a few minutes 1

Speaker: NA
Text: shall read what I did say.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Whe n we come to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party ( Mr Fadden) it is still more diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult to state his position, because in his

Speaker: NA
Text: second-reading speech on this measure

Speaker: NA
Text: he attacked one of the vital principles

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 1945 legislation, namely, that deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with the special accounts which the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks have to lodge with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank. He derided the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument of the Government that that

Speaker: NA
Text: fund was established as a safeguard

Speaker: NA
Text: against secondary inflation. I t waa

Speaker: NA
Text: established by his own Government, but

Speaker: NA
Text: he derides it now. I n effect, he says

Speaker: NA
Text: " Let us disregard secondary inflation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and give the banks back their money,

Speaker: NA
Text: and let them invest it, not at 1 per cent.,

Speaker: NA
Text: but at any per cent, they can get".

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Text: I did not say anything

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sort.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman implied that. He can make

Speaker: NA
Text: clear to the country where he stands on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Warringah

Speaker: NA
Text: has suggested that there may be shares

Speaker: NA
Text: in an Australian private bank which are

Speaker: NA
Text: not compulsorily acquired on the date

Speaker: NA
Text: specified in a notice given under clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 13, that these shares may belong to Eng-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish shareholders and that the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: these shares may fall before they are,

Speaker: NA
Text: in due course, vested in the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank. The honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: can rest assured that i f these shares are

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently acquired the position of any

Speaker: NA
Text: such shareholders shall not in any way be

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudiced by the fact that their shares

Speaker: NA
Text: were acquired by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank at a later date than in the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian shareholders.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has exhausted his time.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Text: Warringah) [8.27] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Information ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Calwell) has given us a second-reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech on clause 46, and for the second

Speaker: NA
Text: time we have heard him going back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the depression. He and his colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: can never extricate themselves from the

Speaker: NA
Text: bog of the depression. He rested all his

Speaker: NA
Text: arguments upon conditions which may

Speaker: NA
Text: have obtained 20 or 30 years ago, but

Speaker: NA
Text: which have no bearing on the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem confronting ns to-day. He

Speaker: NA
Text: drew attention to the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: interest which was charged by pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate banks over a period of 50 years

Speaker: NA
Text: had resulted in substantial profits,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he conceded that they do not make

Speaker: NA
Text: those profits now, nor have they made

Speaker: NA
Text: them for some years past. I t is well

Speaker: NA
Text: that this point should be clarified,

Speaker: NA
Text: because that has never been a real issue

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate. We admit that there

Speaker: NA
Text: should be control over interest rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: control over the general policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: advances, control over currency, control

Speaker: NA
Text: over credit and central bank operations,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, consequently, control over the ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate profits of the private banks. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: that was the policy pursued by the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment of which I was a member

Speaker: NA
Text: during the war, as was conceded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. So it is to-day. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: controls, which, without any doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever, are matters with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: banking which could not be successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: challenged-an d if they were, this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: falls to the ground-remov e all the

Speaker: NA
Text: abuses the Minister complained about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the only reason for this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation is for the purpose of vesting com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete control of all financial transactions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is inherent in the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: speech something to which I draw first

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Chifley), because our experience

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber is that, whilst his MinisCourt

Speaker: NA
Text: ters say one thing he, himself, says

Speaker: NA
Text: another. The Minister for Information

Speaker: NA
Text: says, " Why not remove the shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: of the banks? There are 75,000 of them,

Speaker: NA
Text: and half of them do not reside in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. That is a good reason why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should take over the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks". I find that difficult to undervision

Speaker: NA
Text: stand, particularly in view of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's statement this afternoon about

Speaker: NA
Text: how people are going to invest their

Speaker: NA
Text: money in this country. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: Government believes that the Commonpensation;

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth should take over a business beany

Speaker: NA
Text: cause foreign capital is invested in it,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister say so, and not leave

Speaker: NA
Text: it to the Minister for Information to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the disclosure. That is what was

Speaker: NA
Text: said, and that was clearly what the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister had in mind. His words were,

Speaker: NA
Text: " That was a good reason why the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks should be taken over by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, because one half of the shares were

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by English capital". Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite should do their utmost

Speaker: NA
Text: to encourage the investment of more

Speaker: NA
Text: British capital in Australia, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavouring to destroy confidence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of this country by statements such

Speaker: NA
Text: as those which the Minister made. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: futile for the Prime Minister to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: of attracting British capital to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: when he permits the Minister to make

Speaker: NA
Text: statements of that kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have directed attention to the need

Speaker: NA
Text: to give some firm basis of consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to the position of the English share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders in private banks in Australia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not yet received a reply. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: this part of the bill, two classes of share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holder are dealt with. One is the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian shareholder in the banks, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are set out in Part I . of the first schedule.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the shareholders whose shares

Speaker: NA
Text: will be taken over under clause 13. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: there are other shareholders to whom

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 22 applies, under which the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth will take over the assets as

Speaker: NA
Text: distinct from the shares of the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. Regarding both of those

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of shareholders, Part IV .

Speaker: NA
Text: provides that in the event of an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement not being reached between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the shareholders in the

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, or the Government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks in the second instance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue may be determined by the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: of Claims. The problem to which

Speaker: NA
Text: I directed attention is a problem which

Speaker: NA
Text: affects British and foreign shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is all very well for the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that we can rest assured that those

Speaker: NA
Text: persons will get a fair go. I prefer, i f I

Speaker: NA
Text: may say so, to see an appropriate pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the bill. This is what

Speaker: NA
Text: can happen. Under clause 13, those who

Speaker: NA
Text: hold shares on the Australian register

Speaker: NA
Text: may receive notice of the taking over of

Speaker: NA
Text: the the shares, leaving them rights of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: but the bill does not contain

Speaker: NA
Text: provision with respect to taking over

Speaker: NA
Text: let the shares of English shareholders. The

Speaker: NA
Text: position, then, is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will take over the Australian shares, and

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint its own directors who, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, will have complete power to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: on in any way they think fit for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of selling the assets to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank, and finally winding up the

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs of the private banks. Then, the

Speaker: NA
Text: time will come when the directors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian banks, who are the mere

Speaker: NA
Text: nominees of the Government or the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank, will decide the terms

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which liquidation shall take place,

Speaker: NA
Text: and tbe assets be handed over. The in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terests of the English shareholders will

Speaker: NA
Text: depend upon the nature of the bargain

Speaker: NA
Text: that the liquidators or directors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company ultimately make with the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank. The .bill should make

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for the English shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The position can easily be met by hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing an appropriate amendment inserted

Speaker: NA
Text: in the bill when the Senate is considering

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I t could be dealt with by a provision

Speaker: NA
Text: that any English shareholder, who felt

Speaker: NA
Text: aggrieved with the amount paid to him

Speaker: NA
Text: for his shares or for his interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: private hank, should have the right to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the matter before the Federal Court

Speaker: NA
Text: of Claims. That is a reasonable pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Otherwise, he would be left

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely in the hands of the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: without redress. The directors might be

Speaker: NA
Text: following the policy which they think fit

Speaker: NA
Text: and which they believe to be in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terests of the Commonwealth Bank, but

Speaker: NA
Text: their decisions can vitally and adversely

Speaker: NA
Text: affect the interest of the British share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders. I ask the Prime Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: give me an assurance that some provision

Speaker: NA
Text: will be made to enable the English share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holder, if he feels aggrieved in the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances which I have described, to

Speaker: NA
Text: have recourse to the Federal Court of

Speaker: NA
Text: Claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier, the Prime Minister replied to

Speaker: NA
Text: a question as to how this transaction will

Speaker: NA
Text: be financed. It is agreed that approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately £100,000,000 is involved. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for "Wentworth ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harrison) pointed out, the available

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed assets in the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank are not sufficient for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of financing a trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: action of this magnitude. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said, " Well, it can be dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: as an ordinary trading advance. Here,

Speaker: NA
Text: the assets are being transferred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank. It, can advance

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Spender.

Speaker: NA
Text: the money for the purpose of acquiring

Speaker: NA
Text: these assets". I f that argument be

Speaker: NA
Text: correct-it s shallowness will be revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly-w e can say that all Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth public works can also be financed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Commonwealth Bank, because

Speaker: NA
Text: assets are created, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank can provide the requisite capital,

Speaker: NA
Text: and additional taxe9 need not be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of meeting it. I f that

Speaker: NA
Text: argument be correct, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: could nationalize any business in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia by merely increasing the liabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth' in terms of bonds

Speaker: NA
Text: or currency which is available in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t requires no exemplification to prove

Speaker: NA
Text: that if we increase the liabilities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, whether in the terms of increased

Speaker: NA
Text: currency circulating in the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: or of securities, we must vitally affect the

Speaker: NA
Text: national economy. To that matter, little

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration has been given. I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: only when the Prime Minister was forced,

Speaker: NA
Text: by constant requests as to how the trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: action would be financed, to refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject, that we received this extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary reply. All I have to say is that

Speaker: NA
Text: if that is the way in which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposes to finance the affairs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the country^ it will not be long before the

Speaker: NA
Text: people realize that the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation for financial wizardry is

Speaker: NA
Text: purely a myth. I t is fantastic to pretend

Speaker: NA
Text: that any transaction, no matter what

Speaker: NA
Text: amount is involved, whether it be

Speaker: NA
Text: £100,000,000 to cover the taking over of

Speaker: NA
Text: the private banks or £1,000,000,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of nationalizing many indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, can be financed simply by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank increasing the liabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country, without serious conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quences to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the reasons which I have stated,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister should reply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: statements of the Minister for Informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Does the Prime Minister stand, or

Speaker: NA
Text: does he not stand, by the Minister's state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that, because nearly one half of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in the private banks are held for

Speaker: NA
Text: the most part by shareholders in Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain, that is a good reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth should take over

Speaker: NA
Text: with the banks? Let the Prime Minister say

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Minister has expressed his

Speaker: NA
Text: views. I f he does not agree with that

Speaker: NA
Text: statement, let him make his position clear,

Speaker: NA
Text: because this is exceedingly important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, I ask the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman to give an undertaking in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of English shareholders. They

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be obliged to rely upon what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever government is in office at the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The life of the present Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly come to a close. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite may laugh, but they know

Speaker: NA
Text: that my statement is true. For this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, the writing is already on the

Speaker: NA
Text: wall. I t will not be long before it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be out of office, as it deserves. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 should like to know what the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister proposes to do about compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the private banks incorporated

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere. These are referred to in Part

Speaker: NA
Text: [ II . of the first schedule. So far as

Speaker: NA
Text: able to see, the effect of this part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will be that none of the banks, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those in Part III . of the first

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule, namely, the Bank of China, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank of New Zealand and the Comptoir

Speaker: NA
Text: National d'Escompte de Paris, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted to function in Australia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill does not contain any provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: compensating them i f clause 46 of the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is relied upon-a s it could be exclusively

Speaker: NA
Text: -t o destroy the private banks. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to show that my interpretation of

Speaker: NA
Text: these provisions is wrong; but I have yet

Speaker: NA
Text: to discover in the bill that these institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions will be compensated for the business

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would lose in these circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances.

Speaker: Mr FALSTEIN
Text: Watson) [8.40] -

Text: The honorable member for Warringah

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Spender) referred to the arrangedepartment,

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which the Prime Minister (Mv.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley) said have been made for financsimilar sum.

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the acquisition of the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: assets of the private banks as being in the

Text: nature of a hoax. Nothing could be

Speaker: NA
Text: ther from the truth. I f the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member were to spend more time in the

Text: Parliament he could have found out

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements had been made in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. I n the first place, clauses

Speaker: NA
Text: to 46 provide for two separate parts. The

Text: first part, namely Part VI . , contains

Text: divisions, the first of which provides

Text: acquisition of assets. Part VII . is a part

Speaker: NA
Text: have offered strong objection because

Speaker: NA
Text: banking in this country. Before dealing

Text: to refer to some of the arguments which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been advanced by Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers in relation to Part VI . I t has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said that no clear indication has

Speaker: NA
Text: been given to the Parliament, or the

Text: country, as to how the assets of the private

Text: banks are to be acquired by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank - The honorable member

Text: for Wentworth ( Mr Harrison) and

Text: other " notable financial authorities"

Speaker: NA
Text: have given a variety of figures purport-

Text: ing to be the actual capital of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank. Before the suspension

Text: of the sitting for dinner the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: I am -raemher for Wentworth said that the

Text: assets amounted to £14,000,000. I do not

Text: know whether he then said that he only

Speaker: NA
Text: " thought " that was their value, but later

Text: he said that he thought the assets were

Text: valued at £22,000,000. He referred to

Text: the annual report of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank. Any one who wants to obtain in-

Text: formation about the capital of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank has only to read thd

Text: Commonwealth Bank Act of 1945. The

Text: figures' that I shall give to the committee

Text: Savings Bank, but only the central bank

Speaker: NA
Text: functions and general trading activities

Text: of the Commonwealth Bank. The 1945

Text: act provides that the central banking

Text: department of the Commonwealth Bank

Text: shall have a capital of £4,000,000; its

Text: general banking division a capital of

Speaker: NA
Text: £4,000,000; the rural credits division a

Speaker: NA
Text: capital of £2,000,000; the mortgage bank

Speaker: NA
Text: a capital of £4,000,000, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the industrial finance department a

Speaker: NA
Text: That makes a total

Speaker: NA
Text: and authorized capital of £18,000,000.

Text: Th e capital of the

Speaker: NA
Text: furCommonwealth Bank, as set out in its

Speaker: NA
Text: last report, is £16,392,000.

Text: I shall not accept

Speaker: NA
Text: what the honorable member's figures

Text: I have taken them

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 from the bank's balance-sheet.

Text: Th e argument

Speaker: NA
Text: two would seem to turn on the actual capital

Speaker: NA
Text: for of the Commonwealth Bank or what is

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by way of capital. I merely

Speaker: NA
Text: the draw the attention of the committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: what is provided for in the 1945 act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bank may use up to £18,000,000 in those

Speaker: NA
Text: it various divisions that I have mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie basis of tbe argument of tbe Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is false; its members refer merely

Speaker: NA
Text: to the capital of the Commonwealth Bank,

Text: without reference to its assets, whereas

Text: they refer to the assets of the private

Text: banks without mentioning liabilities to

Text: shareholders. Opposition members who

Text: want the actual figures can have them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The act provides for the utilization of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital up to £18,000,000 distributed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the way that I have already mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Excluding the Commonwealth Savings

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank, the assets of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank as at the 30th June, 1947, were

Speaker: NA
Text: valued at £730,883,858. That figure must

Text: be considered in relation to the amount of

Text: capital which the bank is authorized to

Text: use should it so desire. For the purposes

Text: of comparison I shall read from a state-

Text: ment relating to the Australian banking

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics which has been circulated among

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable .members. I t is true that the

Text: figures are not given as at one date, but

Text: it appears to me, from a cursory examina-

Text: tion of them, that they all fall within

Text: the one quarter. The returns have not

Text: been made as at the 30th June in each

Text: instance, as some of them cover periods

Text: or the 14th October. However, as they

Text: all fall in the one quarter, it is fair to

Text: cite them. They show that the total

Text: shareholders amount to £71,426,770. The

Speaker: NA
Text: assets of the private banks, also covering

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse periods, but coming within the

Speaker: NA
Text: same quarter, are shown to be

Speaker: NA
Text: £839,432,222. That is merely illustrative

Speaker: NA
Text: of the fact that whereas, on the one hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: the trading banks have liabilities to their

Text: shareholders amounting to

Speaker: NA
Text: £71,000,000, their assets amount to more

Speaker: NA
Text: than £839,000,000. The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank has an authorized capital of about

Speaker: NA
Text: £18,000,000 in its central bank and trad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing section-tha t is, exclusive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Savings Bank-bu t its

Speaker: NA
Text: assets exceed £700,000,000; so that what-

Text: ever arguments are advanced by the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, no accountant would deny that a

Text: considerable sum of money is available

Text: to the Commonwealth Bank, either im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately or over a period of months.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a positive limitation to what

Text: can be done.

Text: What about the excess

Speaker: NA
Text: and what is being done. On this subject

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister in his second-reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech said-

Text: In acquiring the business of the private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks the Commonwealth Bank will also

Text: assume the liabilities of these institutions.

Text: necessarily have regard to this factor, and

Text: it will be well within the capacity of the

Text: Commonwealth Bank to meet the payments

Text: from its own resources. ' The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank will make payment in cash or govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment bonds as desired.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing could be more explicit. I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to Part VII . of the bill, which includes

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 46. This is the clause which pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: hibits the carrying on of banking business

Text: by the private banks. Not one argument

Text: over, while the whole of their attention

Text: and shares. I t would appear that mem-

Text: bers of the Opposition do not want to give

Text: by way of objection to this legislation.

Speaker: NA

Text: case rest upon the objections which they

Text: have so far taken. When they are blown

Text: they will use the second string to their

Text: over bow. I hope that before the " guillotine "

Text: sition about clause 46. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA

Text: gested that they would be. So that even

Speaker: NA

Text: confused. Two acts relating to banking

Speaker: NA
Text: was an act relating to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank, providing for the abolition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Bank Board,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the substitution for it of

Speaker: NA
Text: direct control by a Governor, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer, on all matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: which was the abolition of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank Board, and the substituting

Speaker: NA
Text: for i t of direct control by a Governor,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Treasurer ,on all matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. The second piece of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Banking Act-no t the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank Act-bu t the Banking Act

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1945, and it contained various pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions regarding special

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts. As the matter had been speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fically dealt with in the Parliament, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the special deposit accounts. A state-

Speaker: NA

Text: about the Commonwealth Bank Act-

Speaker: NA
Text: not the Banking Act-an d it was made

Text: He in these terms- I quote from page 759 of

Text: Hansard, for the 21st March, 1945. I

Text: sents our view. I t is as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, on behalf of my colleagues and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: House and to the people that, when we on

Speaker: NA

Text: board control to the Commonwealth Bank,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a complete restoration of parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: authority i n this matter. I n every other

Speaker: NA
Text: respect we shall hold ourselves obliged in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantly to review the working of this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion w i t h the object of bringing i t into line

Speaker: NA
Text: with what we believe to be the stable require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was the only statement made, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it was made in relation to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank Act. A l l who were here

Text: during those debates would at once agree

Text: with me in that. The statement had no

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the Banking Bill of 1945, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequently the suggestion that some

Speaker: NA
Text: portions of the 1945 Banking Act, which

Text: by me on behalf of the Opposition is

Text: of 1945 which enable the central bank

Speaker: NA
Text: this piece of legislation, which seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: go far beyond the Banking Act of 1945,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the individual, in his individual trans-
