Text: Australia.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: A s I am reminded

Speaker: NA
Text: by my colleague, the fight against this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill has been referred to as the second

Speaker: NA
Text: battle f or Australia. Whenever a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressive Labour Government introduces

Speaker: NA
Text: progressive legislation i n connexion w i th

Speaker: NA
Text: banking the same extravaganza of mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: representation and distortion takes place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dire happenings prophesied by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition i n 1911 did not come to pass.

Speaker: NA
Text: The f r i g h t f u l consequences that were

Speaker: NA
Text: prophesied to follow the Banking A c t

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1945, which we are told the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion parties now approve, did not come

Speaker: NA
Text: to pass. Yet the same arguments are

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced against the 1947 legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us see what one distinguished mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: her of the community had to say on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of banking. I refer to Pro^

Speaker: NA
Text: fessor Walter Murdoch, of the University

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Australia, now a very old

Speaker: NA
Text: man. A f t e r dealing w i th the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: banking i n the Melbourne Herald and i n

Speaker: NA
Text: other newspapers-som e other news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers which regularly printed his syn-

Speaker: NA
Text: dicated articles would not prin t this one

Speaker: NA
Text: -Professo r Murdoch had this to say-

Speaker: NA
Text: My conclusion, not come to all of a sudden

Speaker: NA
Text: nor without due thought, is that our money

Speaker: NA
Text: system-th e regulation of the issue and recall

Speaker: NA
Text: of currency and credit on a rational .and

Speaker: NA
Text: scientific basis-i s far too important, far too

Speaker: NA
Text: vital to tlie welfare of all of us to be left to

Speaker: NA
Text: private profit making firms. I t is the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern of the nation. We talk of responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: governments; if there is one thing a respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible government ought to be responsible for,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is surely this.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a very sound statement f r o m the.

Speaker: NA
Text: viewpoint of the average citizen. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: epitomises the Government's viewpoint.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not desirous of destroying i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry which we ourselves helped to

Speaker: NA
Text: create. We are not anxious to destroy the

Speaker: NA
Text: solvency of the country, f or which we

Speaker: NA
Text: alone are responsible. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious to upset the lives of the people,

Speaker: NA
Text: who to-day are not oppressed by the fear

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had during the depression, the

Speaker: NA
Text: fear that they would not be able to get

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I f the workers of Australia are

Speaker: NA
Text: to lose any freedom under this b i l l, i t

Speaker: NA
Text: will be only the freedom to starve. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are tryin g to ensure that they shall not

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer f r o m that fear of want that so

Speaker: NA
Text: many-a t least 700,000 workers at one

Speaker: NA
Text: time and 400,000 workers at another

Speaker: NA
Text: time-suffered .

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: Wh y is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister addressing his remarks to his

Speaker: NA
Text: own supporters?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Becaus e I regard

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member as being com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely hopeless. I t is of. no use f o r me to

Speaker: NA
Text: cast my pearls i n certain directions.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we nationalize the banks and

Speaker: NA
Text: when we rationalize banking procedure,

Speaker: NA
Text: i t may be found by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank authorities that the trading banks'

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders have been making, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: an inordinate profit overall, but also a

Speaker: NA
Text: profit i n certain directions in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: should not have been allowed to profit

Speaker: NA
Text: at all. I refer to the payment of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: change on cheques, a charge to which

Speaker: NA
Text: every person livin g i n the country areas

Speaker: NA
Text: is subject, whereas city residents are

Speaker: NA
Text: largely exempt. When the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank Board takes control of

Speaker: NA
Text: banking in this country, exchange may be

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminated. I f so, there will be a great

Speaker: NA
Text: saving to the primary producers. Fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: thermore, when the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: takes charge of banking in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: it will probably be found possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce interests rates on rural indebted-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness, and perhaps on housing loans, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of people living in both the city

Speaker: NA
Text: and the country, to a far greater

Speaker: NA
Text: degree than ever before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank Act 1945, we tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to translate into legislative actuality

Speaker: NA
Text: something that had been a part of our

Speaker: NA
Text: platform for many years. On the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party's platform we had this statement,

Speaker: NA
Text: " The financing by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank at the actual cost of issuance and

Speaker: NA
Text: services of public work". The legal

Speaker: NA
Text: draftsmen, when they interpreted our

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes in the legislation, provided

Speaker: NA
Text: that loans should be made for housing

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes at " the lowest practicable rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of interest". That was the desire of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and of the nation. I n my

Speaker: NA
Text: view, a rate near 2 per cent, would be

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable. Some day we shall get down

Speaker: NA
Text: to that rate, but we shall not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so while we have nine trading banks

Speaker: NA
Text: cluttering the way. The sooner we get

Speaker: NA
Text: rid of those banks the sooner shall we be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to govern the nation in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the whole population.

Speaker: Mr LANG
Text: Eeid) [10.23] - I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to clause 46, sub-clause (1), which

Speaker: NA
Text: reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1.) Notwithstanding anything contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in any other law, or in any charter or

Speaker: NA
Text: other instrument, a private bank shall not,

Speaker: NA
Text: after the commencement of this act, carry

Speaker: NA
Text: on banking business i n Australia except as

Speaker: NA
Text: required by this section.

Speaker: NA
Text: I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That, in clause 46, sub-clause (1.),

Speaker: NA
Text: word " section", tlie following words be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: serted:-"provid e that such prohibition shall

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply to co-operative banks constituted in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the rules governing the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of co-operative societies, such co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative banks for the purposes of this act

Speaker: NA
Text: not being regarded as private banks."

Speaker: NA
Text: In moving that amendment, I desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that co-operative banking is in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the fundamental prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples of the Labour movement. I t is also

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute safeguard to the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: movement. I t is a protection against

Speaker: NA
Text: monopoly control of banking by anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour governments. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers know that nowhere has the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative movement flourished more than

Speaker: NA
Text: on the coal-fields of our country. There

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-operatives have acted as banks for

Speaker: NA
Text: the miners during every major indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial crisis. Without the co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, the miners would have lost every-

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial battle that they fought from

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the the time of the notorious leg-irons to the

Speaker: NA
Text: present date. What would have happened

Speaker: NA
Text: had anti-Labour governments been in

Speaker: NA
Text: power during those disputes i f the present

Speaker: NA
Text: bill had been in operation? During their

Speaker: NA
Text: disputes the miners have invariably sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vived because of the credit extended to

Speaker: NA
Text: them by the co-operative movement. The

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operative societies work on bank over-

Speaker: NA
Text: drafts. They also virtually operate as

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, creating their own form of credit

Speaker: NA
Text: which they supply in order to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: miners and their families. However, a

Speaker: NA
Text: hostile anti-Labour government, under

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill, could stop the credit of the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operatives and, by calling up the over-

Speaker: NA
Text: drafts instead of extending them, apply

Speaker: NA
Text: economic pressure to the workers on the

Speaker: NA
Text: coal-fields and elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill assumes that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth monopoly bank will always be-

Speaker: NA
Text: a Chifley bank. Under this bill, i t might

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time be a Menzies bank, a Casey

Speaker: NA
Text: bank, or even a Thornton bank. What

Speaker: NA
Text: would have happened had this bill been in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation in the 'twenties? Then i t

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been a Bruce bank or a Page

Speaker: NA
Text: bank. What would have happened to the

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operatives on the coal-fields during in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial disputes then? The first thing

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been that the bank, by order

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government, would have called up

Speaker: NA
Text: their overdrafts and that would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: after the the end of the struggle. The Miners

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation could never have survived a

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis without the assistance that its mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers received from the co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: movement. Yet, unless provision is made

Speaker: NA
Text: in this bill for the co-operative banks, all

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-operative societies in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be at the mercy of any future

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-Labour government. The miners

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be able to last a month in an

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial dispute because, under this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: they would be beaten to their knees im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately. The Government and its sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters must realize that when they pass

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill they create a Menzies bank or a

Speaker: NA
Text: Casey bank. They will be giving the

Speaker: NA
Text: anti-Labour forces control by monopoly

Speaker: NA
Text: just as surely as they are creating a pass-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Chifley monopoly. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to be blinded to the future just

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is to the past. Unless i t makes pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision for co-operative banks-an d I say

Speaker: NA
Text: this deliberately-i t will be forging the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest weapon that the anti-Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: movement has ever had presented to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: These imion funds will be at the mercy

Speaker: NA
Text: of an anti-Labour banking monopoly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer of the day will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: freeze trade union funds. Think of what

Speaker: NA
Text: would have happened to the timber

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in 1929 i f other sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour movement had been unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to their assistance, as they would be

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to do when this bill becomes law,

Speaker: NA
Text: and an anti-Labour government takes

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of the treasury bench! Think of

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Bruce-Page Government could

Speaker: NA
Text: have done then! By making provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for co-operative banks, this .Government

Speaker: NA
Text: could protect the trade unions of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and the Australian workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Co-operative banks are not run for

Speaker: NA
Text: private profit nor are they run for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of a few privileged

Speaker: NA
Text: persons, but among the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. The Co-operative Whole-

Speaker: NA
Text: sale Society's Bank in England has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a most successful institution. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was started in 1872 by the society as a

Speaker: NA
Text: loan and deposit department. The co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative movement in Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: then obtained an amendment of the act

Speaker: NA
Text: that made it possible to transform that

Speaker: NA
Text: department into a bank. That was in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1876. Since then the co-operative move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Great Britain has had its own

Speaker: NA
Text: bank, conducted by its own members, and

Speaker: NA
Text: with directors elected by its members.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bank not only acts as a banker for

Speaker: NA
Text: the society itself; it acts as a banker for

Speaker: NA
Text: 11,866 trade union accounts. It acts also

Speaker: NA
Text: for mutual organizations, as well as mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the co-operative movement and

Speaker: NA
Text: any one else who wishes to utilize its

Speaker: NA
Text: services. It is also banker for 95 local

Speaker: NA
Text: governing bodies. It has its head-quarters

Speaker: NA
Text: in Manchester and it has branches in

Speaker: NA
Text: other cities, and agencies f>*" receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lang.

Speaker: NA
Text: deposits and cashing cheques in various

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operative institutions throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: land. That Co-operative Bank is a safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guard against monopoly banking in

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain. I t does not operate for

Speaker: NA
Text: the sake of private profits. I t pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides banking facilities at absolutely the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum cost; but it does more than

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I t not only pays a high rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest on deposit accounts, but it also

Speaker: NA
Text: pays interest at the rate of l i per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: on current accounts and that is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that neither the private banks nor the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank has yet done. I f a

Speaker: NA
Text: worker deposits his money with the Corn-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank in a cheque account he

Speaker: NA
Text: receives no interest on i t ; but the bank

Speaker: NA
Text: lends the money at a high rate of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest. I f the Co-operative Bank in

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain can pay interest on current

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts, why cannot the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank in Australia do likewise? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank is merely a replica

Speaker: NA
Text: of the private trading banks and it has

Speaker: NA
Text: all their vices. I t is profit-hungry, and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no guarantee under this measure

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will change its habits. Co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive banks, operating in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: the principles of the co-operative move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, would be conducted on altogether

Speaker: NA
Text: different lines. A co-operative bank

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a democratic institution and

Speaker: NA
Text: not a monopolistic institution. Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union funds would be safe in a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of industrial crisis, and the co-operati. e

Speaker: NA
Text: bank could extend credit just as the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative societies do to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the Government rejects this amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, it is not sincere in its attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental Labour principles. Accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to its latest balance sheet, last year

Speaker: NA
Text: the Co-operative Bank in England had

Speaker: NA
Text: a turnover of £1,311,000,000. Its assets

Speaker: NA
Text: now amount to £473,000,000 and after

Speaker: NA
Text: paying £500,000 in interest on current

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts it still showed a very substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial surplus for distribution amongst ics

Speaker: NA
Text: members. The co-operative movement

Speaker: NA
Text: regards banking as the bridge between

Speaker: NA
Text: production and distribution and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the true function of banking. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unions in this country have refused

Speaker: NA
Text: to bank with the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have been afraid of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment interference at a time when they

Speaker: NA
Text: were engaged in an industrial struggle.

Speaker: NA
Text: That fear will be intensified unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government gives protection by making

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for co-operative banks.

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: Wha t unions are they?

Speaker: Mr LANG
Text: Practicall y all of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government supporters should ask themdestroys

Speaker: NA
Text: selves: What is going to happen to the

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts of the trade unions and Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations when anti-Labour governmaking

Speaker: NA
Text: ments control the monopoly Commonwhich

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank? Unless they vote

Speaker: NA
Text: for this amendment they will be making

Speaker: NA
Text: voting to hand over the funds of if

Speaker: NA
Text: the trade unions and the labour organiHigh

Speaker: NA
Text: zations to the enemies of Labour when

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemies of Labour are in power.

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Government will give

Speaker: NA
Text: serious consideration to the amendment,

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the sake of the trade unions,

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and the co-operatives, I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the amendment will be accepted.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: New. England) [10.39].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I wish to say something to-night about

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks made by the honorable memwent

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Dalley ( Mr Eosevear), who gave

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members a lecture on ethics.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member quoted Lord he

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan, the distinguished English

Speaker: NA
Text: lord, with regard to the ethics of

Speaker: NA
Text: barristers, and then proceeded to comhonorable

Speaker: NA
Text: plain about the professional conduct of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Warringah duct in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Spender). I t i l l became the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dalley to lecture any-

Speaker: NA
Text: body on ethics after his own unethical

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct in the labour movement in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. The gross manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member betrayed his predeparty

Speaker: NA
Text: cessor in the electorate of Dalley, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: E. G. Theodore, is not beyond the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: memory of members of this committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and of the public generally. The honorgot

Speaker: NA
Text: able member had been secretary to Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Theodore in the previous election camment

Speaker: NA
Text: paign, and had learned the whole inner

Speaker: NA
Text: workings of the machine of that elecScullin

Speaker: NA
Text: torate. He then preceeded to stab in

Speaker: NA
Text: back the man he was supposed to support.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tell the Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley)

Speaker: NA
Text: that neither the leopard nor the leper

Speaker: NA
Text: changes his spots: and there have been

Speaker: NA
Text: signs that the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dalley is organizing the rank and file

Speaker: NA
Text: of the present Government to do the

Speaker: NA
Text: kindly deed towards him as he did tothe

Speaker: NA
Text: wards Mr Theodore, when the latter

Speaker: NA
Text: was the member for Dalley. So, it

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes this paragon of virtue to strut

Speaker: NA
Text: and parade himself in this chamber as

Speaker: NA
Text: one who should lecture other honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members when we know that his history

Speaker: NA
Text: is the history of a political assassin who

Speaker: NA
Text: the people he is pledged to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port. The other night we witnessed the

Speaker: NA
Text: spectacle of the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: an attack upon the High Court,

Speaker: NA
Text: is the highest judicial tribunal in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. What was his reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: that attack? He was determined,

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, to lower the prestige of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Court in the eyes of the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, or to terrify the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: I the court. He failed in both of those

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives. He did not lower the court

Speaker: NA
Text: the in the eyes of the people; and he did

Speaker: NA
Text: not terrify the members of the court.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will not be terrified by the idle

Speaker: NA
Text: threats of a. man like the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Dalley. I t i l l became him to do

Speaker: NA
Text: what, he did. During the week-end he

Speaker: NA
Text: to Sydney, and discovering the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: percussions of his speech against the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment and against himself, personally,

Speaker: NA
Text: now returns and indulges in a torrent

Speaker: NA
Text: law of abuse of honorable members. The

Speaker: NA
Text: public of Australia can judge what the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dalley is worth by

Speaker: NA
Text: his conduct in this chamber, and his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Information ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Calwell) said that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank Board should not be re-established,

Speaker: NA
Text: the and that the objection of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: to a bank board is just as strong

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day as i t was in 1945 and 1924. The

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there are great gaps in the

Speaker: NA
Text: memory of the Minister, because he for-

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell the committee that the Banking

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill introduced by the Scullin Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1930 provided for the reappoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a bank board. What did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government do? I t was a Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: the government, and we are told that Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: governments never change their views.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister did not tell the people that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Scullin Government, not only pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to re-appoint the bank board, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it also appointed Sir Robert Gibson, who,

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day, is condemned by all honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: same members opposite as the arch enemy of

Speaker: NA
Text: workers of this country, not for one

Speaker: NA
Text: year but for seven years, and gave him

Speaker: NA
Text: i l l powers which the honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite say should not he given to any

Speaker: NA
Text: man. Honorable members talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: wanting a people's bank and not a

Speaker: NA
Text: bankers' bank. They try to mislead the

Speaker: NA
Text: people by these phrases, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: central bank must be a bank for the trad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing banks. The Royal Commission on

Speaker: NA
Text: Monetary and Banking Systems recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended that the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: should also have the function of a trad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing bank in order to enable it to discip-

Speaker: NA
Text: line the trading banks by active competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with them in carrying out fully the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of a trading bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Information talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about the setting up of a regional court

Speaker: NA
Text: of appeal to protect the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: man on the land. How would the man

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land obtain satisfaction from

Speaker: NA
Text: such a court, provision for which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: made even in this bill, although the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister referred to such a tribunal in

Speaker: NA
Text: his second-reading speech? How could

Speaker: NA
Text: the man on the land obtain satisfaction

Speaker: NA
Text: from such a court after his experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: having to wait month after month to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain advances from the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank to enable him to stock his land or

Speaker: NA
Text: to purchase implements and such articles

Speaker: NA
Text: as cornsacks for the handling of his

Speaker: NA
Text: crops? The Labour party is purely a

Speaker: NA
Text: city-controlled party, which does not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand in the slightest degree the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of the man on the land,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it puts forward such a superficial

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition as that and expects the man

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land to believe it. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Information also said that the trad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing banks charged internal exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: upon cheques. If that was such an evil,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has had two years to

Speaker: NA
Text: abolish it in respect of the transactions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Bank; but it has

Speaker: NA
Text: not done anything in that direction. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the word of the Minister for Informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the Government is thus guilty

Speaker: NA
Text: of gross insincerity. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister it has robbed the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia by charging internal

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange on all cheques handled by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank. Then we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposition that with one monopoly

Speaker: NA
Text: bank the interest rate will be reduced to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 per cent, or, indeed, to zero. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been anything to prevent the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank from reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of interest below the present rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Abbott.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Royal Commission on Monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: and Banking Systems pointed out, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank reduced the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of interest charged by all of the pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: houses of Australia to a figure that was

Speaker: NA
Text: considerably lower than the rate pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously charged. The bank did that

Speaker: NA
Text: simply by making funds available

Speaker: NA
Text: at a low rate of interest to two,

Speaker: NA
Text: or three, pastoral houses, the remainder

Speaker: NA
Text: of those institutions being obliged to fall

Speaker: NA
Text: into line. There has been nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent the Commonwealth Bank, which,

Speaker: NA
Text: since the passing of the 1945 banking

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, has been in the fullest com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition with the trading banks, from

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the rate of interest and forcing

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the trading banks to come into

Speaker: NA
Text: line. But i t did not do so. Is it likely,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it has a monopoly of banking in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, to behave differently from

Speaker: NA
Text: other monopolies? No. The monopoly

Speaker: NA
Text: bank will screw the people just as hard

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future as it has in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: With regard to the amendment moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Reid ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lang) to provide for the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of co-operative banks, we in the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industries are vitally interested in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal. Probably, he has a much

Speaker: NA
Text: greater knowledge than I have of the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of co-operative movements on

Speaker: NA
Text: the coal-fields and of the requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: of people living in those districts; but I

Speaker: NA
Text: say that in no industry in Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-operative movement taken deeper

Speaker: NA
Text: root than in the dairying industry. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: my own electorate and the adjoining

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Robertson, there are two of

Speaker: NA
Text: the largest co-operative butter factories

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. One of those factories

Speaker: NA
Text: desired to extend its operations to a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable degree, and on being refused

Speaker: NA
Text: an advance for this purpose by one trad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing bank, i t obtained the accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: it desired from another private bank. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other establishment, the Singleton-Wara-

Speaker: NA
Text: tah butter factory, wished to establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: selling floor in Sydney for its whole milk

Speaker: NA
Text: trade, and when it failed to obtain accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation from one trading bank it ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained the accommodation it desired

Speaker: NA
Text: from another trading bank. No one

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in primary industry believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that economists and bureaucrats, who

Speaker: NA
Text: possess only book learning, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seized with the necessity for the establishinstrument

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of industries of that kind in dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tricts where practical men know them to

Speaker: NA
Text: be essential. The economists and bureau-

Speaker: NA
Text: crats, live in the detached air of Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra, far removed from the scenes

Speaker: NA
Text: where, in blood and sweat, the farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: produce the food to feed the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do we think for a moment that we shall

Speaker: NA
Text: get any better accommodation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of our co-operative fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories from this monopoly institution

Speaker: NA
Text: than we did in the past? Therefore, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the duty of the Government to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment. I have great pleasure

Speaker: NA
Text: in supporting it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Fremantle) [10.51] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall address most of my remarks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Eeid ( Mr Lang) has moved in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to co-operative banking. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that in the volley of abstract nouns

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honorable member for New

Speaker: NA
Text: England ( Mr Abbott) discharged in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, there is very much to answer;

Speaker: NA
Text: but the honorable member for Eeid has

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed a problem which, he states, will

Speaker: NA
Text: confront trade unions in the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial disputes when this bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: passed. The political career of the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member may be summed up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: -expression "right wing actions and left

Speaker: NA
Text: wing slogans ". I feel that to-night, in

Speaker: NA
Text: advancing one of the arguments that the

Speaker: NA
Text: private banks have put forward, he has

Speaker: NA
Text: borne out that striking feature of his

Speaker: NA
Text: political career. I f a trade union is on

Speaker: NA
Text: -strike in defiance of an arbitration court

Speaker: NA
Text: award, and i f the Government, in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to enforce that award, passes legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: impounding its funds, i t is immaterial

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the funds are in a private bank,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank or a State sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings bank. The power which this Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has to enforce laws with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to industrial peace under the conciliation

Speaker: NA
Text: and arbitration power would enable i t

Speaker: NA
Text: to over-ride a private bank in precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: the same way as i t would over-ride the

Speaker: NA
Text: -Commonwealth Bank. Therefore, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main point of the honorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: argument there is no merit whatever. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: was advanced, of course, with the idea of

Speaker: NA
Text: alarming the trade unions with the

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that in the hands of the political

Speaker: NA
Text: parties opposed to the Labour party, the

Speaker: NA
Text: "Commonwealth Bank could be used as an

Speaker: NA
Text: against them. Even without

Speaker: NA
Text: the nationalization of banking, the funds

Speaker: NA
Text: of a trade union in a private bank could

Speaker: NA
Text: be impounded by a government which

Speaker: NA
Text: was disposed to impound them. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: that point perfectly clear at the outset.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Banking Bill, there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: no greater disadvantage to a trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: in the event of the Liberal party and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Country party coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: power than under the present system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second remark of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Eeid related to the formation

Speaker: NA
Text: of co-operative banks. That i t was a

Speaker: NA
Text: phantasy is shown by the fact that in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the subject of co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: banks, he cited English examples, and

Speaker: NA
Text: then, by making play with the word " co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative ", he spoke about how the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative stores, although he did not use

Speaker: NA
Text: the word " stores " but that was what he

Speaker: NA
Text: meant, had carried various trade unions

Speaker: NA
Text: during strikes. He left us to infer that

Speaker: NA
Text: this was being done by co-operative banks

Speaker: NA
Text: established by trade unions. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are no co-operative banks estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished by trade unions in Australia, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that that particular phantasy which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member brought forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: bolster up his amendment, and to give

Speaker: NA
Text: him an excuse to echo in the name of the

Speaker: NA
Text: left the slogans of the right, was as

Speaker: NA
Text: invalid as his suggestion that there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: menace to the trade unions in the bill in

Speaker: NA
Text: its present form.

Speaker: NA
Text: The clauses under consideration relate

Speaker: NA
Text: to the assessment of compensation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibit the private banks from carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: on banking business. I t is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: notice that the Federal Court of Claims

Speaker: NA
Text: will be staffed by judges with qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions equal to those of justices of the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court. Sub-clause 2 of clause 40

Speaker: NA
Text: provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: The amount of compensation payable shall,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless agreed upon, he determined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: court and not in any other manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sub-clause 4 of the same clause pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides-

Speaker: NA
Text: Where a notice is given under the last pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceding section in relation to any shares, the

Speaker: NA
Text: persons entitled to payment of compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect to the acquisition of those shares

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be determined by the Court and not in

Speaker: NA
Text: any other manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout these clauses, the absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: authority of the Federal Court of Claims

Speaker: NA
Text: is established by this bill. I desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an observation upon that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been the practice of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court in the past, when determining

Speaker: NA
Text: whether just compensation has been paid,

Speaker: NA
Text: to require only that there shall have been

Speaker: NA
Text: a judicial inquiry into compensation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder, however, whether one clause of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill will be found, upon challenge,

Speaker: NA
Text: to be valid. I refer to the clause which

Speaker: NA
Text: purports to cancel the right of appeal

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Federal Court of Claims to the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court. Since the Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: itself lays down that when the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth acquires property, just compensa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion must be paid for it, the phrase

Speaker: NA
Text: " just compensation " being a part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution, is a part which must be in

Speaker: NA
Text: -the jurisdiction of the only court which

Speaker: NA
Text: can interpret the Constitution, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the High Court. However, that is a.

Speaker: NA
Text: matter for lawyers to determine. '

Speaker: NA
Text: Statements have been made concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the judicial appointments of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, arid I desire to refer to them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley), in answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to a question this afternoon, stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the period of six years during which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has been in office, it had

Speaker: NA
Text: made only one appointment to the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court. That, of course, was the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Sir William Webb, formerly

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief Justice of Queensland. Last week,

Speaker: NA
Text: and during a part of the debate to-day,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has been accused of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tending to pack the High Court. When

Speaker: NA
Text: I asked purely objective questions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister to-day concerning state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Warringah ( Mr Spender) made as

Speaker: NA
Text: statements of fact that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to pack the High Court, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member said that it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair inference. There is a name well

Speaker: NA
Text: known to lawyers given to people who, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: court of law, elevate their inferences into Brennan, F.

Speaker: NA
Text: statements of fact. Now, this denuncia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the appointment of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment either means nothing, or is an

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on the former Chief Justice of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, Sir William Webb, the only

Speaker: NA
Text: appointee of the Government to the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court. If the High Court

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be packed, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: must amend the Judiciary Act, which

Speaker: NA
Text: now provides for the appointment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court of only seven judges. The

Speaker: NA
Text: seventh judge-again I emphasize that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beazley.

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the only appointment that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has made-wa s appointed in

Speaker: NA
Text: April, 1946. He had been the Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Justice of Queensland, and before

Speaker: NA
Text: that a highly qualified and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spected lawyer. The assertions about

Speaker: NA
Text: packing the High Court are either

Speaker: NA
Text: an attack on Sir William Webb or

Speaker: NA
Text: gaseous nonsense, and the people, know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the calibre of that judge, can ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain for themselves that this smear

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign concerning the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: judicial appointments was intended

Speaker: NA
Text: simply as a part of a political rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than an analytical campaign against the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That the words proposed to be inserted ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: LANV -'S amendment) be so inserted'.

Text: WOOL.

Text: the honorable member for Wakefield

Text: ( Mr MCBride) asked a question regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the exportation of wool to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America. The quantities of

Speaker: NA
Text: wool exported to the United States of

Text: Tellers:

Speaker: NA
Text: America during 1946-47 were as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lows :-

Speaker: NA
Text: Wool--Greasy. Wool-Scoured , Tops, Noils

Text: and Waste.

Text: I i i my reply I indicated that i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: be difficult to estimate the quantities of

Speaker: NA
Text: wool to be exported to the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: of America this financial year. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported decline i n wool production i n that

Speaker: NA
Text: country, should mean that i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase additional quantities f r o m Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and so augment our dollar re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources. I have not been able to secure

Speaker: NA
Text: any information regarding United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America's intentions which

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of value to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member.

Text: 1. What is the value per pound of the

Speaker: NA
Text: TOBACCO.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: O n the 4th November,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Indi ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen) asked a question regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: tobacco production in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Commerce and Agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: has supplied the following informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion :-

Speaker: NA
Text: The successful development of tobacco leaf

Speaker: NA
Text: production in Australia is dependent on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of factors and i t is considered that the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important of these are the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: irrigation facilities in suitable growing areas

Speaker: NA
Text: and the control of crop pests and diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The return which the grower will receive for

Speaker: NA
Text: his crop is of importance also, but even high

Speaker: NA
Text: prices cannot compensate a producer whose

Speaker: NA
Text: yields have been seriously depleted by lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: water and the ravages of insects or other pests.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provision and extension of irrigation

Speaker: NA
Text: works and assistance to producers generally

Speaker: NA
Text: are matters for the governments of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing States. The Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has assisted the States from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: in making grants available to supplement

Speaker: NA
Text: work being done in connexion wit h production

Speaker: NA
Text: problems. Last year the Commonwealth ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved of a grant of £10,000 per annum for a

Speaker: NA
Text: five-year period on a £1 for £1 basis to be

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated amongst the producing States of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia for experimental and

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration work in connexion with tobacco-

Speaker: NA
Text: leaf production, particularly in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: control and elimination of diseases and pests.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n addition the Council for Scientific and I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial Research is engaged upon research

Speaker: NA
Text: work connected w i t h the problems of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tobacco industry. On the subject of prices

Speaker: NA
Text: for tobacco leaf, attention is directed to a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent announcement by the Minister f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce and Agriculture that the prices to-

Speaker: NA
Text: be paid to growers are to be increased by tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: 3,099 payment of specific premiums based upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,579 appraisal values placed on leaf. I t is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: that these additional payments w i l l stimulate-

Speaker: NA
Text: 54 production in the industry and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: reward the output of better quality leaf.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other steps which might be taken to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: .. 29 towards a greater production of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: leaf are under examination and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Commerce and Agriculture w i l l take the-

Speaker: NA
Text: . . 1,480 opportunity of discussing this question with

Speaker: NA
Text: .. 209 the State Ministers for Agriculture at the-

Speaker: NA
Text: next meeting of the Australian Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: .. 1 Council.

Speaker: NA
Text: 170 POWER KEROSENE.

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: O n the 13th Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: 105 ber, the honorable member for Swan ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hamilton) asked a question concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie supply of power kerosene to primary on

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. The Minister for Supply and ploitation

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping has supplied the following parations

Speaker: NA
Text: information:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Although power kerosene is in global short

Speaker: NA
Text: supply, there is at present no rationing of

Speaker: NA
Text: power kerosene in Western Australia or any

Speaker: NA
Text: other State, nor has there been any shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: of stock of power kerosene i n Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, but i t is of course possible that on

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions due to transport and other diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties a temporary local shortage of stock

Speaker: NA
Text: may have occurred. I n such cases the local

Speaker: NA
Text: oil company agent would, of course, be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pelled to ration his customers. I t is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered that the local man is best able to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly in such a situation and i t is obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: his own best interests to ensure an equitable

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution of the stocks available. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has no immediate intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: rationing power kerosene, but should future

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances make such action necessary, 1

Speaker: NA
Text: can assure the honorable member that all due

Speaker: NA
Text: regard will be paid to the requirements of that

Speaker: NA
Text: product for both primary producers and all

Speaker: NA
Text: other essential users.

Speaker: NA
Text: CAKE TINS.

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: O n the 12th Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, the honorable member for Deakin

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hutchinson) asked a question con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning the supply of tinplate for cake

Speaker: NA
Text: tin lids. The Minister for Supply and

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping has supplied the following in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation :-

Speaker: NA
Text: Owing to the shortage of supply of tinplate

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacture of cake tins suitable as con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainers for sending cakes abroad is prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: They require a considerable quantity of t i n -

Speaker: NA
Text: plate that cannot be made available for this

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose. Manufacturers of domestic tinware,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are severely rationed in their supplies,

Speaker: NA
Text: do manufacture, however, a re-usable cake t i n

Speaker: NA
Text: as a piece of kitchen equipment. This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely different model and a l i d is neither

Speaker: NA
Text: practicable, necessary or desirable. STo doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the type of t i n to which the question

Speaker: NA
Text: referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: CANCER: CANTASSIUM TABLETS.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Wilmot ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duthie) asked a question concerning an

Speaker: NA
Text: importation at Launceston, Tasmania, of

Speaker: NA
Text: cantassium tablets. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Customs has supplied the

Speaker: NA
Text: following information:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations provide that the importation of

Speaker: NA
Text: medicinal preparations, known as " Cantas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sium ", whether described by that name or

Speaker: NA
Text: any other name shall be prohibited except w i t h

Speaker: NA
Text: the consent of the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The prohibition was enacted many years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice of the Director-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health wit h the object of preventing the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian public with pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: which are considered of no use for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose intended. I n the administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the prohibition, however, authority was

Speaker: NA
Text: given to permit importation of these goods i n

Speaker: NA
Text: cases where the Collector of Customs is satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lied that the cantassium is imported by or for

Speaker: NA
Text: a person who is actually suffering from cancer,

Speaker: NA
Text: that i t is not intended for sale and also that

Speaker: NA
Text: the quantity imported is not more than would

Speaker: NA
Text: be necessary for Buch patient.

Speaker: NA
Text: The parcel o'f cantassium tablets referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by tlie honorable member arrived in Launces-

Speaker: NA
Text: ton on 13th September, 1947. On the next

Speaker: NA
Text: day the importer's agent stressed the urgency

Speaker: NA
Text: i n of the matter and, on being informed of the

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions under which the goods would he

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered undertook to obtain a certificate

Speaker: NA
Text: from the patient's doctor. The agent w.as re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peatedly reminded by the Customs officer deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with the transaction to obtain the doctor's

Speaker: NA
Text: certificate which would have provided

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to release the goods but the certi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficate was not produced. I n the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: such necessary evidence of the intended dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal of the goods and as the importation

Speaker: NA
Text: was in the name of a wholesale chemist,

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery was withheld. I t is understood that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was not until the 19th September that the

Speaker: NA
Text: relatives of the patient were requested by the

Speaker: NA
Text: importer to furnish a doctor's certificate but

Speaker: NA
Text: by that date the patient had died. As there

Speaker: NA
Text: should be very little difficulty i n obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: proof that a person is actually suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: cancer, i t is considered that no alteration from

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing procedure regarding the importa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of cantassium is necessary or warranted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can assure the honorable member that

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie Commonwealth Government would not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: hibit the importation of any drugs recognized

Speaker: NA
Text: by competent authorities to be beneficial in the

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of cancer.

Text: 10. What reserve ( i f any) has been created

Text: 1945-40 and 1D40-47.. and how many dwelling*

Speaker: NA
Text: PETROL RATIONING.

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: the

Speaker: NA
Text: representiug the Minister for Supply and

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. I n view of the fact that i t h:is been

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded that a number of motor vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying eastern States registration plates have

Speaker: NA
Text: been seen in Western Australia, w i l l he inform

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie House what check, i f any, is exercised

Speaker: NA
Text: the movement of such vehicles?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. As the existing petrol ration does not

Speaker: NA
Text: permit sufficient coupons being issued to

Speaker: NA
Text: motorists t o make overland trips from the

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern States to Western Australia, what

Speaker: NA
Text: check, i f any, is kept on the sale of petrol for

Speaker: NA
Text: such purposes i n the eastern States and en

Speaker: NA
Text: route from there to Western Australia?

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: Th e Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply and Shipping has supplied the

Speaker: NA
Text: following information:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Instructions were issued recently to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquid Fuel Control Boards in all States that

Speaker: NA
Text: long distance travel by motor vehicle should

Speaker: NA
Text: bo eliminated i n respect of both business and

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly pleasure journeys, unless there

Speaker: NA
Text: are very urgent reasons for justifying such

Speaker: NA
Text: travel such as the owner of the vehicle being

Speaker: NA
Text: on permanent transfer from one State to

Speaker: NA
Text: another and unable to arrange for the transport

Speaker: NA
Text: of his vehicle by either boat or rail.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since these instructions were issued, infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation such as that brought t o notice by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member has been received by the

Speaker: NA
Text: various fuel boards, which are taking special

Speaker: NA
Text: action to check the position and eliminate all

Speaker: NA
Text: unessential travel of this nature.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, a conference is being held in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne this week at which all Liquid Fued

Speaker: NA
Text: Boards will be represented. This conference

Speaker: NA
Text: will, in conjunction with a recently constituted

Speaker: NA
Text: oil advisory committee, consider a l l aspects

Speaker: NA
Text: associated wit h the control of motor spirit,

Speaker: NA
Text: including action necessary to eliminate un-

Speaker: NA
Text: authorized journeys of the type referred t o by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH DISPOSALS

Speaker: NA
Text: SION : SALES TO MOUNT MARGARET

Speaker: NA
Text: MISSION.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs BLACKBURN asked the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Supply and

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Is i t a fact that representatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Margaret Aborigines Mission in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Australia requiring certain goods from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Disposals Commission were informed that only

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent, discount would be allowed?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. I f so, can a more generous discount even

Speaker: NA
Text: to SO or 75 per cent, be allowed in view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that about 300 aborigines would benefit,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the mission would be able to obtain a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater quantity of urgently needed material

Speaker: NA
Text: with its very limited resources?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Is i t a fact that, in two cases when

Speaker: NA
Text: application was made for certain lines and

Speaker: NA
Text: the 20 per cent, discount concession was quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the mission representatives, well over 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, was added to the purchase price above

Speaker: NA
Text: the price quoted when the samples were in-

Speaker: NA
Text: spected, and that the mission had to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Will he allow a 10 per cent, deposit on

Speaker: NA
Text: the goods bought and arrange for the balance

Speaker: NA
Text: to be paid in twelve months?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Can arrangements be made for free

Speaker: NA
Text: railway freight for all goods for aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: use consigned over Commonwealth Railways?

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. I f i t be possible to take such action for the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of this group of aborigines, can similar

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions be granted in regard to disposals

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of other aboriginal groups?

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. An allowance of 20 per cent, discount

Speaker: NA
Text: was granted to the mission. I t is emphasized,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that this discount was off wholesale

Speaker: NA
Text: rates or cost, whichever was the lower.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Tbe Commonwealth Disposals Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: is not a retail organization but gives special

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to the needs of welfare organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The commission has no authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: dispose of surplus government property other

Speaker: NA
Text: that at fair market prices. Hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: requests from charitable institutions and

Speaker: NA
Text: other deserving bodies for concessional treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are received and any relaxation of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure would create a precedent difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: resist in other directions. Under special Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sury authority, certain approved charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations are provided through the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Salvage Controller with used cloth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and blankets' without payment, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Margaret Mission has obtained a very

Speaker: NA
Text: large quantity of garments and other mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: rials from this source without charge.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. No. See answer to question No. 1.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. In accordance with Treasury instructions,

Speaker: NA
Text: sales effected by the commission are cash upon

Text: RAIL TRANSPORT: BURIAL o» MR .

Speaker: NA
Text: V. H . ALLEN .

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Interior, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Was the late Mr V. H. Allen the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial officer of the Commonwealth Railways for

Speaker: NA
Text: over twenty years, with service dating back

Speaker: NA
Text: to before the Trans-Australian railway was

Speaker: NA
Text: constructed ?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Did Mr Allen die while on duty at

Speaker: NA
Text: Zanthu*, a small siding on the Trans-Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian railway, in the Minister's electorate?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Was an a pplication made on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: relatives for the remains to be brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, which was Mr Allen's head-quarters

Speaker: NA
Text: and place of residence?

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Was the request refused by the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner, Mr Gamin?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. I f so. did the late Mr Allen's long and

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent support of the Commissioner and the

Speaker: NA
Text: exceptional circumstances surrounding his

Speaker: NA
Text: death warrant the request being granted?

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Text: Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Z. Yea.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: :i, 4 and 5. Immediately advice was received

Speaker: NA
Text: hy the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr Allen had died, directions were issued,

Speaker: NA
Text: even before the relatives had been informed

Speaker: NA
Text: of his death, that the body waa to be brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to Melbourne by the first train for interment.

Speaker: NA
Text: All freight charges on the casket were paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Railways Department.
